posts.creator: Augustin Popa
posts.title: What‚Äôs New in vcpkg (June 2025)
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
This blog post summarizes changes to the vcpkg package manager as part of the 2025.06.13 registry release, 2025-04-16, 2025-05-19, and 2025-06-02 tool releases, as well as changes to vcpkg documentation throughout May and June. This release includes bug fixes, several documentation changes, and the removal of the x-gha binary caching provider for GitHub (alternatives are described below).
Some stats for this period:
There are now 2,621 total ports available in the vcpkg curated registry. A port is a versioned recipe for building a package from source, such as a C or C++ library.
35 new ports were added to the curated registry.
517 ports were updated. As always, we validate each change to a port by building all other ports that depend on or are depended by the library that is being updated for our 15 main triplets.
132 community contributors made commits.
The main vcpkg repo has over 6,900 forks and 25,100 stars on GitHub.
vcpkg changelog (2025.06.13 release)
The following notable changes were made in this release:
Due to recent changes in GitHub Actions Cache‚Äôs API, the x-gha binary caching provider has been rendered obsolete. As a result, we had to remove it from vcpkg (PR: Microsoft/vcpkg-tool#1662). Instead, you can use one of the following methods to cache binaries in GitHub; we welcome any feedback from our users about how this experience could be improved in the future:

Use GitHub Packages with NuGet, which uses vcpkg‚Äôs caching mechanism and preserves caching granularity per port. This is the method the vcpkg team recommends.
Use actions/cache in your workflow to cache the installed directory. The downside of this method is that the whole installed tree gets cached as a single artifact, so single port updates invalidate all packages.
Fixed a bug causing permissions while using upkg to not be preserved (PR: Microsoft/vcpkg-tool#1625).
Improved diagnostics and bug fixes for vcpkg x-test-features command (PRs: Microsoft/vcpkg-tool#1649, Microsoft/vcpkg-tool#1650, Microsoft/vcpkg-tool#1663, Microsoft/vcpkg-tool#1676, thanks @autoantwort!).
Fixed an issue causing slow binary cache insertions in some Docker containers (PRs: Microsoft/vcpkg-tool#1659, Microsoft/vcpkg-tool#1669, thanks @Thomas1664, @dg0yt!).
Other minor bug fixes and internal feature improvements (thanks @autoantwort, @dg0yt, @huangqinjin, @DewJunkie!).
Documentation changes
The vcpkg docs have moved to the MicrosoftDocs organization, under the URL https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/vcpkg-docs. The existing repo has fully migrated with no loss in functionality. Links to the old repo should redirect to the new one automatically. The experience on the Learn website remains the same.
Added documentation for the new commands format-feature-baseline and x-test-features (PR: MicrosoftDocs/vcpkg-docs#455).
Added documentation for vcpkg license-report command (PR: MicrosoftDocs/vcpkg-docs#491).
Updated Tutorial: Set up a vcpkg binary cache using GitHub Packages in a GitHub Actions workflow to clarify that mono is no longer pre-installed by default for GitHub Actions Ubuntu runners (PR: MicrosoftDocs/vcpkg-docs#495).
Updated vcpkg in MSBuild projects article to add instructions about how to pass MSBuild properties to vcpkg builds (PR: MicrosoftDocs/vcpkg-docs#481).
Removed documentation references to GitHub Actions Cache and x-gha provider, de-indexed the associated tutorial, and added a removal notice on the reference page.
Other minor documentation improvements (thanks @Alan Pope, @Ivan Sorokin, @shijunz, @Tiago Freitas, @Yan Romao!).
If you have any suggestions for our documentation, please submit an issue in our GitHub repo or see the box at the bottom of a particular article.

While vcpkg supports a much larger variety of target platforms and architectures (as community triplets), the list above is validated exhaustively to ensure updated ports don‚Äôt break other ports in the catalog.
Thank you to our contributors
vcpkg couldn‚Äôt be where it is today without contributions from our open-source community. Thank you for your continued support! The following people contributed to the vcpkg, vcpkg-tool, or vcpkg-docs repos in this release (listed by commit author or GitHub username):

Learn more
You can find the main release notes on GitHub. Recent updates to the vcpkg tool can be viewed on the vcpkg-tool Releases page. To contribute to vcpkg documentation, visit the vcpkg-docs repo. If you‚Äôre new to vcpkg or curious about how a package manager can make your life easier as a C/C++ developer, check out the vcpkg website ‚Äì vcpkg.io.
If you would like to contribute to vcpkg and its library catalog, or want to give us feedback on anything, check out our GitHub repo. Please report bugs or request updates to ports in our issue tracker or join more general discussion in our discussion forum.

posts.title: An inside look at Meta‚Äôs transition from C to Rust on mobile
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
Have you ever worked is legacy code? Are you curious what it takes to modernize systems at a massive scale?
Pascal Hartig is joined on the latest Meta Tech Podcast by Elaine and Buping, two software engineers working on a bold project to rewrite the decades-old C code in one of Meta‚Äôs core messaging libraries in Rust. It‚Äôs an ambitious effort that will transform a central messaging library that is shared across Messenger, Facebook, Instagram, and Meta‚Äôs AR/VR platforms.
They discuss taking on a project of this scope ‚Äì even without a background in Rust, how they‚Äôre approaching it, and what it means to optimize for ‚Äòdeveloper happiness.‚Äô
Download or listen to the episode below:

You can also find the episode wherever you get your podcasts, including:
Spotify
Apple Podcasts
Pocket Casts
The¬†Meta Tech Podcast¬†is a podcast, brought to you by Meta, where we highlight the work Meta‚Äôs engineers are doing at every level ‚Äì from low-level frameworks to end-user features.
Send us feedback on¬†Instagram,¬†Threads, or¬†X.
And if you‚Äôre interested in learning more about career opportunities at Meta visit the¬†Meta Careers¬†page.

posts.title: New Livestream ‚Äì Troubleshooting Spring Boot Applications with the Spring Debugger
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
Join us for a new IntelliJ IDEA Livestream episode with Marco Belher and explore how to uncover and fix Spring Boot bugs using the Spring Debugger in IntelliJ IDEA. 
Date: July 17, 2025
Time: 3:00‚Äì4:00 pm UTC
REGISTER FOR THE LIVESTREAM




Session abstract
Spring Boot hides a lot of complexity to help you build applications quickly. But when things go wrong ‚Äì misconfiguration, incorrect bean injection, or tricky transaction behavior ‚Äì debugging rapidly becomes complicated.
In this stream, we‚Äôll use the Spring Debugger for IntelliJ IDEA to explore real-world issues in Spring Boot applications. Whether you‚Äôre just getting started or already deep into production systems, you‚Äôll learn how to uncover hidden problems, understand what‚Äôs really going on in your app, and find and fix issues in the code.
We‚Äôll walk through live examples, from simple mistakes to tricky bugs, and show how the IDE helps you troubleshoot step by step.
Asking questions
Marco will try to answer all of your questions during the session. If we run out of time, we‚Äôll publish answers to any remaining questions in a follow-up blog post.
Your speaker and host
Speaker
Marco Behler
Marco works as a developer advocate at JetBrains in Munich, Germany. He loves to share everything he knows about writing and building awesome software ‚Äì knowledge he acquired from a decade of consulting in the Java and Spring ecosystems ‚Äì through guides, tweets, books and talks.
Host
Andrey Belyaev
Andrey Belyaev is a product manager on the IntelliJ IDEA Ultimate team. He works on various plugins and is now primarily focused on cloud and deployment support in IntelliJ IDEA.
Happy developing!

posts.creator: Irina Mariasova
posts.title: Java Annotated Monthly ‚Äì July 2025
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
Welcome to the July edition of Java Annotated Monthly! This issue is packed with fresh articles, helpful tips, and ideas to keep you inspired and motivated in your work.
We‚Äôre excited to feature Aicha Laafia, a Java engineer passionate about writing clean, green code and empowering women in tech. She‚Äôll share how sustainable coding practices improve performance and reduce energy usage, and why mental well-being deserves just as much attention in our field.
You‚Äôll also get a first look at the new Spring Debugger in IntelliJ IDEA ‚Äì a powerful tool that reveals what‚Äôs really going on inside your Spring Boot app and helps you fix issues faster.
As always, we‚Äôve gathered insightful notes on AI, upcoming events in July, and a few tech-adjacent thoughts to spark reflection and curiosity. Let‚Äôs dive in! üöÄ
Featured Content¬†
Aicha Laafia

I‚Äôm Aicha Laafia, a Java software engineer with a love for coding, an interest in sustainability, and a commitment to empowering women in tech. I am a Women Techmakers and Girls Code ambassador, a member of the Moroccan Association of Computing Science, and part of the JetBrains Community Contributor program.
 
I focus on creating software with minimal environmental impact while mentoring and supporting women in technology. When I‚Äôm not coding, I enjoy exploring delicious food, phone photography, and watching Formula 1.

I‚Äôm excited to share what I‚Äôm passionate about: making Java apps not just clean and fast, but also greener and more efficient.
Clean code keeps you sane at 2am. Green code keeps your infrastructure costs sane at scale. It‚Äôs also more interesting! You have to squeeze performance out of what you have with no sloppy code hiding behind overkill hardware.
One of the biggest sources of wasted resources is start-up and warm-up time. Microservices and serverless functions spin up and down constantly. Every millisecond wasted during startup is wasted CPU cycles and energy.
This is why I would love to introduce one of JDK 24‚Äôs game-changing features, Ahead-of-Time Class Loading (JEP 483). It preloads and links classes before runtime, slashing startup and warm-up lag. Faster startup means microservices waste fewer CPU cycles, directly cutting energy use in cloud-native environments. I‚Äôve covered this in detail in my article JDK 24: Faster, Smarter, and Ready for the Future.
Pair this with GraalVM 24.2‚Äôs native image capabilities ‚Äì near-instant start-up and a low memory footprint ‚Äì and you get serious energy savings and better performance.
Looking ahead to JDK 25 and beyond, they‚Äôre adding some solid improvements for performance and efficiency:
JEP 514 and JEP 515 bring better ergonomics and profiling for Ahead-of-Time compilation, making startup faster and CPU use smarter. I am super excited about JEP 521, which enhances Shenandoah GC with generational collection, cutting pause times and improving memory management.
If you want to dive deeper into practical green coding with Java, check out my Green Programming 101 article series. If video is more your thing, here‚Äôs my recent live talk at vJUG: How to Build Sustainable Java Applications.
Before I say goodbye, remember there‚Äôs one resource we often overlook: ourselves. Just like we monitor and optimize CPU and memory, it‚Äôs crucial to monitor your mental health and watch for burnout. It‚Äôs a hidden struggle many developers face. If you want to learn more, check out my article on The Duck Syndrome: A Hidden Struggle for IT Professionals.
Enjoy this month‚Äôs Java Annotated Monthly. üöÄ
Java News

posts.creator: Kodee
posts.title: Kodee‚Äôs Kotlin Roundup: A Carefully Curated June Edition
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
It‚Äôs time for another edition of Kodee‚Äôs Kotlin Roundup! If June flew by while you were deep in development, don‚Äôt worry ‚Äì I‚Äôve gathered all the ecosystem highlights for you in one handy digest. Here‚Äôs what you might have missed.
Kodee-approved monthly spotlight
Kotlin 2.2.0 released
Kotlin 2.2.0 is here! This release brings in new and stable language features, tooling updates, performance boosts across platforms, and a bunch of important fixes. I‚Äôve got the official blog post right here ‚Äì give it a read!
Read the full blog post
                                                    
Rich errors in Kotlin
During KotlinConf 2025, Michail Zareƒçenskij, Kotlin‚Äôs Lead Language Designer, explored a smarter way of handling errors. In his talk, he looked at how Kotlin‚Äôs nullability model can be generalized to restricted union types for better error handling.
Watch now
                                                    
KotlinConf 2025 talks and photos are now available
Couldn‚Äôt make it to KotlinConf 2025? No worries ‚Äì all session recordings and event snapshots are now online. It‚Äôs like reliving the whole thing all over again! We‚Äôll also be uploading all the talk recordings to our YouTube channel, so stay tuned and prepare to explore the latest in Kotlin from wherever you are!
Browse and enjoy
                                                    
Kotlin for AI-powered app development
AI in Kotlin projects? You bet! We‚Äôve launched a new documentation page showcasing how Kotlin is used in real-world AI scenarios. Peek into the Kotlin-AI-Examples repository and learn more about Koog, the Kotlin-based AI agentic framework.
Explore Kotlin for AI
                                                    
Kotlin for server-side development
Ktor 3.2.0
The newest Ktor release adds some serious firepower: two new modules for dependency injection and HTMX, support for Gradle version catalogs, automatic configuration deserialization, Unix domain socket support for CIO, and much more.
Read on
                                                    
Kotlin Multiplatform with Compose Multiplatform
Implementing Compose Hot Reload
With Compose Hot Reload, you can edit code and see changes live ‚Äì no app restart needed. A great talk at KotlinConf shows how it works and how you can use it in your projects to make iterating on UI code faster, more convenient, and more exciting.
Watch now
                                                    
Get answers to your KMP questions
The KotlinConf 2025 Closing Panel couldn‚Äôt cover everything live, so we gathered answers to some of the most popular Kotlin Multiplatform questions in a follow-up blog post (because good questions deserve good answers).
Explore the Q&A
                                                    
New Kotlin Multiplatform course on LinkedIn Learning 
A shiny new LinkedIn Learning course is here to help you master Kotlin Multiplatform. Learn how to make smart architectural choices between Compose Multiplatform and native UIs,  create shared networking layers with Ktor, persist data with SQLDelight, and more.
Start learning
                                                    
What else is new
Gradle 9.0.0-rc-1 
Our friends over at Gradle have been busy ‚Äì Gradle 9.0.0 RC1 is out and ready for testing! The highlights include an update to Kotlin 2.1, which means new language features in the DSLs. Want all the details? I‚Äôve got the link!
Check out Gradle 9.0.0-rc-1
                                                    
Guessing developers‚Äô incomes (KotlinConf 2025 edition)
What do Kotlin developers really earn? At KotlinConf 2025, we played a salary guessing game ‚Äì some guesses were spot on, others were hilariously off. Would you like to test your instincts?
Watch and guess with us
                                                    
Kotlin YouTube highlights
Kotlin Notebook Upgrade: Smoother UI and More Stability
Kotlin Multiplatform (KMP) at McDonald‚Äôs
Build your own NES Emulator with Kotlin | Artur Skowro≈Ñski
Kotlin Clean Architecture for Serverless: Business Logic You Can Take Anywhere | Elena van Engelen
Compose Multiplatform for iOS: Ready for Production Use | Sebastian Aigner
Klibs.io ‚Äì The Dream of Creating a Kotlin Package Index | Ignat Beresnev
Coroutines and Structured Concurrency in Ktor | Simon Vergauwen
IoT Development With Kotlin | Erik Hellman
That‚Äôs all for June! While you‚Äôre rewatching conference talks or experimenting with new features, I‚Äôll be right here keeping an eye on the Kotlin ecosystem for next time. Until then ‚Äì happy coding!

posts.creator: Mala Gupta
posts.title: Module Import Declarations: No More Import Hell¬†
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
Imagine you are proud of yourself for creating an amazing Java application, framework, or a library. You open one of its source files to make some changes and this is what you see:
import java.lang.reflect.*;
import java.nio.file.Path;
import java.io.BufferedReader;
import java.io.InputStreamReader;
import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;
import java.util.stream.Collector;
import java.util.concurrent.CompletableFuture;
import java.util.concurrent.locks.ReadWiteLock;
import java.time.LocalDateTime;
// more import statements
While looking at this long list of imports, are you wondering why you need to know the name of every single class or interface used in your class (apart from its configuration)? It seems like a cognitive load to me. Most of the developers I know collapse this section in their IDE and don‚Äôt bother expanding it.
The business logic in this source file probably starts after line twenty. Can you do something about it because importing packages won‚Äôt help much. Don‚Äôt worry, Module Import Declarations can help address this import hell for you.
What is ‚ÄòModule Import Declarations‚Äô?
Introduced as a preview feature in Java 23 and a production feature in Java 25, Module import declarations enable you to import an entire module using a single import statement. In the above example, you can replace all the import statements with the following line of code, since all those packages are defined as part of the java.base module:
import module java.base.*;
Yes, just one line of code. The source file can now use List, Map, Stream, Path, and many more classes. As a developer, you no longer need to think about which package they live in. With this single statement, you can import all of the packages exported by the module java.base.
Why should you care about this feature?
Apart from the obvious benefits of concise code and escaping from the import hell, this feature helps us developers focus on solving business problems rather than finding the fully qualified names for classes or interfaces to use. Do you think it is worth your time to find out whether the interface Function is defined in the package java.util.function or java.util?. An intelligent IDE such as IntelliJ IDEA helps you to get around it by adding the relevant imports as soon as you use a type in your code (more about it in a later section in this blog post).
It offers convenience for new developers. Imagine you are a new Java developer. Would you prefer having an umbrella import statement so that you need not be bothered about knowing which package defines the commonly used data structures, such as List, Map, or Stream? If you are teaching Java, talking about importing classes interfaces from packages before folks get comfortable using basic data structures could make them lose focus. It would be better for them to get started writing programs that use List and Stream, rather than having them figure out which Java package defines them. Module import declarations help beginners focus on learning Java without getting confused or frustrated by things they don‚Äôt need to worry about yet.
It enables faster prototyping. When we are prototyping, we try to get things to work as quickly as possible. In such cases, an umbrella import statement, such as the import module declaration, lets us jump straight into coding. It also keeps the code concise, cleaner and easier to read when we are using large APIs. But this doesn‚Äôt imply that you should define your code in a module to use a module import statement.
Before moving forward, let‚Äôs cover the IntelliJ IDEA configurations for using this feature.
IntelliJ IDEA Configuration
Import Module declaration was introduced as a preview feature in Java 23 and IntelliJ IDEA has supported this feature since version 2024.3. In soon to be released Java 25, it becomes a production feature (it is now a permanent language feature, and safe to use in your production code).¬†
Java 25 is scheduled to be released in September 2025. To use this feature as a production feature (without needing the --enable-preview flag during compilation and runtime), you should download the early access version of JDK. You can also do this from IntelliJ IDEA‚Äôs settings dialog (Yes! IntelliJ IDEA allows you to download and configure EA versions of the JDK):




In your Project Settings, set the SDK to Java 25. For the language level, select ‚ÄòX ‚Äì Experimental features‚Äô on both the Project and Modules tabs. This enables you to use all Java 25 features, including those currently under review. Java 25 is due to be released in September 2025, and we at JetBrains are working on adding more support. New language options will be accessible in IntelliJ IDEA soon.
More about Module Import Declarations
Knowing why we need a feature is the first step to using it. Let‚Äôs look at how to use it and also answer some frequently asked questions from developers about this feature.
Syntax of Module Import Declarations
The syntax is simple. It starts with the keyword import, followed by module and the name of the module (without a wildcard, that is, *):
import module java.base.*;
This feature doesn‚Äôt work with unnamed modules. Revisit the syntax of this feature: it requires you to name the module you want to import. The example in this section imports the java.base module. 
How to determine the fully qualified name of types in your source code?
Are you wondering how to determine the fully qualified name of a type or variable in your source code when using import module declarations? This was one of the main reasons for using individual imports in source files. This applies to all types of imports, including wildcard and static imports.
Move your cursor to the type in a variable declaration and use the Quick Documentation feature (Ctrl+Q for Win/Linux, or F1 on macOS) to view a documentation popup that shows the package name at the top, followed by the name and its documentation‚Äîwithout having to open another source file in your editor window. You can also use the Quick Definition feature (Ctrl+Shift+I) to view the fully qualified name, along with the definitions of its members, in a popup window. Alternatively, you can hover over the type using your mouse to view the fully qualified name.




On a separate note, if you don‚Äôt like showing Quick Documentation popups on mouse hover, you can clear the ‚ÄòShow quick documentation on hover‚Äô checkbox in the settings (find it using Shift+Shift). If you want to browse the source code of the used type, use the ‚ÄòGo to Declaration or Usages‚Äô feature (Ctrl+B / Cmd+B), which opens the source code in a new editor window.
In the next section, let‚Äôs see how to use the import module statement with different libraries or APIs.
How to import JUnit 3.8.1 using import module declaration?
I know it is an old version, but it is still around and in use. How would you import classes and interfaces defined in JUnit 3.8.1 (if you had to) in your source files? To import it using an import module declaration, you must use its module name. The short answer is you cannot because there is no module name for it. JUnit 3.8.1 was created before Java 9 introduced modules.
What about other libraries? How do we find their module names? We usually use build tools, such as Maven, to import dependencies as jar files. If a dependency supports modules, its jar file includes module-info.class (mandatory for modules), which contains the module name. You‚Äôll notice that the JUnit 3.8.1 jar doesn‚Äôt include module-info.class.
IntelliJ IDEA users can view module info in External libraries, in the Project Structure window, as¬† shown below:




Of course, you could ask the AI Chat window in IntelliJ IDEA how to find these module names.
Which packages are exported by the modules you import?
Each module defines a module-info.java file that includes information about the packages that module exports to all modules or to specific other modules.¬†
Let‚Äôs try to understand this by checking out what happens when you import the module java.base using IntelliJ IDEA. Click on the module name in the editor or use the relevant shortcut (Go to Declaration or Usages) and you could view the definition of this module to find out all the modules exported by this module. This is shown in the following gif:




The public API in these packages are available to source files that import these modules.
What do you mean by on-demand import?
Developers often argue about importing a single class or interface versus importing all public entities by importing a package using a wildcard character. Which of these do you think is better?
When you import a module or a package using a wildcard (*), you import types on demand. This means you can use any public class, interface, or entity from a package or module without importing each one individually.
Often, developers ask if importing a full module increases the size of their .class files. The short answer is no. On-demand imports make all public classes and interfaces in the module available to use in a source file, but the compiler includes only those that are actually used in your code.
Name conflicts (compilation error)
When you import one or more modules, it is possible that packages within the same module or across modules define classes with the same name. For an example, in the example code below, code at line number 5 (Date date;) won‚Äôt compile because importing java.base module makes java.util.Date class available, and importing the java.sql module makes java.sql.Date available:
1.¬† ¬† import module java.base;¬† // Makes available java.util.Date
2.¬† ¬† import module java.sql; ¬† // Makes available java.sql.Date
3.¬†
4.¬† ¬† public class NameConflicts {
5.¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† Date date;¬† // compilation error
6.¬† ¬† }
Let‚Äôs assume you want to use the Date class from module java.sql. To address this issue, you could either add a single import statement, as follows:
1.¬† ¬† import module java.base;¬† // Makes available java.util.Date
2.¬† ¬† import module java.sql; ¬† // Makes available java.sql.Date
3.¬† ¬† import java.sql.Date;
4.¬†¬†¬†¬†
5.¬† ¬† public class NameConflicts {
6.¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† Date date;¬†¬†
7.¬† ¬† }
You could also resolve it by using a fully qualified class name, as follows:
1.¬† ¬† import module java.base;¬† // Makes available java.util.Date
2.¬† ¬† import module java.sql; ¬† // Makes available java.sql.Date
3.¬†
4.¬† ¬† public class NameConflicts {
5.¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† java.sql.Date date;¬†¬†
6.¬† ¬† }
IntelliJ IDEA can highlight name conflicts as you type your code. Invoke context actions to view a list of qualified class names (package name + class name) to choose from, as shown below:




If you are wondering whether it is a good idea to import modules since it could lead to namespace conflicts, these issues can occur with importing packages too. Don‚Äôt worry; it results in a compilation error and can be fixed easily.
Also, a module and one of the packages it includes can have the same name. Notice that the module java.sql contains a package java.sql. The fully qualified name of a class or an interface includes its package name, not the name of the module the package is defined in.
Compact Source Files integration
Gavin Bierman mentioned that the idea of this Import Module Declarations came up while the Java team was working on JEP Compact Source Files and Instance main Methods, which aim to reduce the ceremony to learning Java.¬†
Compact source files implicitly import the module java.base. It implies that the new developers can use any public class or interface from the multiple packages exported by the java.base module, without explicit import statements.
JShell Integration
One of the main benefits of using JShell is that it allows you to quickly evaluate expressions, execute code statements or snippets (and much more) without the ceremony of defining classes.
Prior to Import Module Declarations, JShell automatically imported the ten most used packages (and java.lang) so that developers could easily use those classes or interfaces without explicit import statements. However, you still need import statements for classes or interfaces not defined in these packages, such as the LocalDateTime class from the package java.time:




With import module declarations, JShell automatically imports the module java.base. This helps developers use many more classes (such as LocalDateTime), without needing explicit import statement, as shown in the following image:




One import statement to use the entire standard Java API
By importing the java.se module you can use the entire standard Java API in your source file. Here‚Äôs the module information for this module:




The java.se module is an aggregator module. It does not export any package, but requires other modules transitively. In other words, source files importing java.se import the packages exported by modules that are marked required transitive in java.se.
Interview with creators of this feature
We also interviewed the owner of this feature, Gavin Bierman, Programming Language Designer at Oracle.







Gavin mentioned that this feature was co-developed with the JEP Compact Source Files and Instance Main Methods. He covered the differences between single-type imports and type-import-on-demand declarations, explaining what they are and why individuals and organizations prefer one style over the other. He also talked about how the ‚ÄúModule Import Declarations‚Äù feature automatically imports on demand from transitive dependencies of modules. He discussed ambiguous imports and how to deal with them, name ambiguity, and how to submit relevant feedback on this feature to the teams at OpenJDK.
Practical Tips
Practical tips and wisdom are always useful when using a feature.
Migrating your codebases to use import module declarations
I‚Äôd recommend not replacing all the individual import statements or package statements with import module statements in your codebase. Try module imports in new files or when you‚Äôre already touching existing code.
This feature is syntactic sugar; it makes your code more readable but doesn‚Äôt offer any performance benefits. The folks who maintain your code are more important than using the latest shiny features in your codebase. If they understand the code in its existing format, respect that.
Group Your Imports
With module imports, Java offers multiple types of imports, such as, importing modules, importing packages, importing classes/interfaces, and static imports of fields or methods. Grouping imports could make them more readable.
IntelliJ IDEA supports importing types as you type them
Whether you are copy-pasting code or typing it, IntelliJ IDEA adds the relevant imports to your codebase, either automatically or by prompting you to select the correct version to import, as shown in the following gif:




Just in case, the preceding settings don‚Äôt work for you, ensure you have enabled the relevant import settings in ‚ÄòIntentions‚Äô (use IntelliJ IDEA Settings), as follows:




If you haven‚Äôt been using this feature in IntelliJ IDEA, you are missing out on a great user experience.
Summary
Introduced as a preview feature in Java 23 and a production feature in Java 25, Module Import Declarations allow importing an entire module with a single import statement.
Apart from the obvious benefits of replacing multiple import statements with a single import, this feature helps us developers escape import hell. It works only with named modules, not unnamed ones or older libraries without module definitions (such as JUnit 3.8.1). Classes and interfaces are imported on demand. Importing a module makes its public classes/interfaces available, but only those actually used are included by the compiler. Importing multiple modules might lead to class name conflicts, requiring specific imports or fully qualified names.
JShell and compact source files automatically import java.base with this feature. If you want to extend it, try importing the java.se module, which provides access to the entire standard Java API. The release of Java 25 is scheduled for September, but IntelliJ IDEA already supports this feature. Try it out and let us know your feedback.
Happy coding.

posts.creator: Sergei Petunin
posts.title: 10 Remote Development Best Practices
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
The concept of remote development is deceptively simple: spin up your development environment somewhere that‚Äôs not your local machine. The perks range from freeing up local resources to not panicking when your laptop gets stolen.
Yet, there are plenty of pitfalls, including flaky setups, poor visibility, and lousy monitoring. Let‚Äôs look at some best practices of remote development and see what JetBrains has to offer.
1. Get rid of RDP/VNC/VDS
If you‚Äôre still ‚Äúremote developing‚Äù by pixel-streaming, you‚Äôre wasting your time. Real remote development feels local, handles flaky networks gracefully, and scales far beyond your laptop.
Reality check: Streaming your whole desktop is like lugging a cinema projector over SSH. Every keystroke triggers massive pixel redraws, your IDE becomes sluggish, and one lost packet freezes everything. Why move video frames instead of code diffs? Modern remote protocols only send keystrokes and UI deltas. Latency plunges, and your IDE snaps back to life.
2. Stay online, even when you‚Äôre not
Flaky Wi-Fi isn‚Äôt an excuse anymore. A proper remote development client buffers your edits locally, shows a ‚Äúreconnecting‚Äù notice, and pushes your changes when you‚Äôre back online. Linting, inspections, breakpoints ‚Äì they pick up seamlessly. You keep context, and your work never vanishes into thin air.
3. Enterprise-grade orchestration
One VM or container remotely? Sure, great for demos. But ten teams? A dozen projects? Manual SSH scripts crumble fast. You need a Cloud Dev Environment (CDE) orchestrator that addresses the following pain points:

Pain PointHand-Rolled SSH/Docker/VMCDE Orchestrator (e.g., CodeCanvas)
Resource scalingStatic, brittleAuto-scale, auto-stop, snapshots
Environment drift‚ÄúWorks on my machine‚ÄùVersioned templates, pre-built images
ProvisioningManual installsPre-warmed toolchains, secrets, plugins
SecurityOpen SSH risksZero-trust relays, jump servers, air-gapped lockdown
VisibilityDark ‚Äì no metricsDashboards for usage, health, failures





If you‚Äôre not automating this stuff, you‚Äôre putting your team at a disadvantage.
4. CodeCanvas: JetBrains‚Äô answer
We built CodeCanvas to cover every base:
Dev environment templates: Versioned, shareable, based on Docker images (build your own if needed), IDE backends included.
Auto-provisioning: Plugins, VS Code extensions, secrets ‚Äì everything installs itself.
Cost control: Idle workspaces auto-stop, warm-up snapshots and standby pools minimize startup delays.
Zero-trust security: WebSocket relays (no inbound pods), SSH jump servers as needed, and strict clipboard restrictions.
Observability: Real-time dashboards to monitor environment creation, adoption rates, crashes, and idle times.
5. Borrow, don‚Äôt reinvent ‚Äì follow the leaders
GitHub Codespaces: Uses devcontainer.json, spins up on GitHub‚Äôs infrastructure.
Gitpod: Declares workspace configuration via .gitpod.yml, provides consistent branch environments.
Coder: Brings developers and AI coding agents together in secure self-hosted environments on your infrastructure.
CodeCanvas: Scalable Kubernetes-based environments (EKS, AKS, GKE, or your bare-metal clusters) designed for distributed teams.
If you‚Äôre building your own, ask yourself: what do these platforms handle that I‚Äôm missing?
6. Workflow orchestration beats task automation
Creating a VM is just a task. Combining container builds, secret management, post-hooks, health checks, and cleanup ‚Äì that‚Äôs orchestration. True CDE platforms handle this complexity gracefully. If you‚Äôre still scripting ‚Äúdocker run‚Äù in shell scripts, you‚Äôre reinventing the wheel.
7. Short-lived environments are mandatory
If you try to cram everything into a single long-living environment, you‚Äôll just be stuck twiddling your thumbs during branch switches and rebuilds. When environments spin up in seconds, they become disposable. This allows a fresh environment for each feature or code review, tossed away as soon as you‚Äôre done with it. Warm-up snapshots and standby pools have turned ‚Äúcold start‚Äù into a thing of the past. Short-lived CDEs ensure consistency, security, and predictable costs.
8. Security and compliance: don‚Äôt get pwned
Zero trust: Authenticate and authorize every single IDE connection.
Network isolation: Use per-cluster relays and jump servers with no direct SSH. Restrict clipboard actions to prevent data leaks.
Policy enforcement: Align your practices with security benchmarks ‚Äì development environments are vulnerable if left unguarded.
9. Metrics that actually matter
Dashboards aren‚Äôt just window dressing ‚Äì they drive optimization. Get an overview of:
Startup latency: From spin-up to first build or indexing.
Resource utilization: CPU, memory, and I/O per workspace.
Idle time: Triggers for auto-shutdown.
Failure rates: Backend crashes, reconnections.
Use tools like Prometheus/Grafana, Dynatrace, or cloud-native monitoring to correlate developer efficiency with infrastructure health.
10. AI agent support ‚Äì no longer optional
Your CDE orchestration now has to treat AI agents like first-class citizens, not just humans. That means clean APIs, bulletproof permissions, and tight resource controls. Mistakes here mean you‚Äôll find yourself quickly outdated in a landscape where AI isn‚Äôt optional anymore.
Bottom line
If you‚Äôre clinging to RDP, VDI, manual SSH hacks, or one-off VMs, you‚Äôre consciously choosing friction over productivity. Embrace protocol-smart remote dev clients, short-lived environment orchestration, zero-trust security, and meaningful metrics. Whether you adopt CodeCanvas, Coder, Codespaces, Gitpod, or AWS Cloud9 ‚Äì these patterns aren‚Äôt optional if you care about scale, security, and developer velocity.

posts.creator: Eric Shobe,Jared Mednick
posts.title: Seventh-generation server hardware at Dropbox: our most efficient and capable architecture yet
posts.content:encodedSnippet: Fourteen years ago, Dropbox took its first steps toward building its own hardware infrastructure‚Äîand as our product and user base has grown, so has our infrastructure. What started with just a handful of servers has evolved into one of the largest custom-built storage systems in the world. We've scaled from a few dozen machines to tens of thousands of servers with millions of drives. That evolution didn‚Äôt happen by accident. It took years of iteration, close collaboration with suppliers, and a product-first mindset that treated infrastructure as a strategic advantage. Now we‚Äôre excited to share what‚Äôs next: the launch of our seventh-generation hardware platform, now featuring Crush, Dexter, and Sonic for our traditional compute, database, and storage workloads, and our newest GPU tiers, Gumby and Godzilla. To make this leap possible, we dramatically increased storage bandwidth, effectively doubled our available rack power, and introduced a next-gen storage chassis designed to even further minimize vibration and heat. This generation represents our most efficient, capable, and scalable architecture yet‚Äîand it‚Äôll help us as we continue to build and scale helpful AI products like Dropbox Dash. Below, we‚Äôll walk you through how we designed the latest version of our server hardware as well as key lessons we‚Äôll carry into generations to come. @font-face { font-family: 'AtlasGrotesk'; src: url('https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/65dcd70b48edc3a7b446950e/65dce019c63112e617513c94_AtlasGrotesk-Medium-Web-vfl38XiTL.woff2') format('woff2'); font-weight: 500; font-style: normal; font-display: swap; } @font-face { font-family: 'AtlasGrotesk'; src: url('https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/65dcd70b48edc3a7b446950e/65dce019711b648fd1ccd24a_AtlasGrotesk-Regular-Web-vflk7bxjs.woff2') format('woff2'); font-weight: 400; font-style: normal; font-display: swap; } .xf-content-height {margin: 0;} #cta { font-family: AtlasGrotesk,sans-serif; font-size: .900rem; text-decoration: none; background: #f7f5f2; line-height: 1.69; box-sizing: border-box;} #cta-box { padding: 15px 20px 15px 20px; } #cta-hed {font-weight: 500;} #cta-indent {border-left: 5px solid #1e1919; padding-left:20px;} #cta a:link, #cta a:visited {text-decoration: none;} #cta p { margin: 5px 0px 0px 0px; } .dr-theme-dark #cta {background: #000;} .dr-theme-dark #cta-box {border: 1px solid; border-bottom: 0;} .dr-theme-dark #cta-indent {border-left: 5px solid #f7f5f2;} .dr-theme-dark .button {background: #000;} .button { background-color: #1e1919; color: #f7f5f2; height: 2.5rem; padding: 10px 5px 10px 20px; font-size: 1rem; font-weight: 500; line-height: 1.2; transition: all .3s; } .button:hover { background-color: #0061ff; } img {vertical-align: middle; padding: 0px 1px 2px 0px;} .c17-plain-html {margin-bottom: 50px} Dropbox Dash: Find anything. Protect everything. Find, organize, and protect your work with Dropbox Dash. Now with advanced search for video and images‚Äîplus generative AI capabilities across even more connected apps. See what's new ‚Üí Developing our strategy To understand how we got to where we are today, it‚Äôs helpful to understand how we built the infrastructure foundation on which Dropbox runs. Back in 2015, we relocated all US customer data from off-premises hosts to on-site ones. The Magic Pocket team executed a massive migration project, bringing the bulk of Dropbox‚Äôs file storage into our own custom-built infrastructure. Over 90% of the roughly 600PB of data we stored at the time was moved into data centers we managed ourselves‚Äîa turning point that enabled better performance, cost control, and scale. In the years following, we continued to grow‚Äîa lot. We ramped from 40PB of storage in 2012 to over 600PB by 2016. And today, we‚Äôre in our exabyte era, running on semi-custom hardware that we‚Äôve designed to meet the unique needs of our platform. Along the way, we introduced new technologies such as SMR drives, which allow for higher storage density, and GPU accelerators for AI and compute-heavy tasks. And we‚Äôve co-designed both hardware and software to serve our evolving workloads. So, before committing to any designs for our seventh-generation server hardware, we set some high-level goals that drew from both what we‚Äôd learned from previous generations and opportunities from the latest hardware advancements in the industry. Three primary themes shaped our approach: Embracing emerging tech Infrastructure hardware is evolving fast. CPUs are getting more powerful with higher core counts and better performance per core. AI workloads are growing rapidly. Networks are moving toward faster speeds like 200G and 400G. And a new band of storage areal density has finally arrived. We used this moment to guide our strategy, aiming to harness these trends to improve our performance, efficiency, and scalability. Partnering with suppliers Strengthening these relationships also continues to give us a strategic edge: We get earlier access to emerging technology, deeper hardware customization, and a more stable platform.¬† Designing with software in mind We brought in our software teams early to find out what would actually move the needle for their services. That led to goals like packing more compute power into each rack, enabling GPU support for AI and video processing, and improving speed and responsiveness for our database systems. Co-designing was a central theme; we weren‚Äôt just designing servers, but building platforms that elevated our services. All of these goals converged around a central question: How big of a leap do we want to make, and what technologies will help get us there? Instead of maxing out everything just because we could, we focused on what matters most: better performance per watt, higher rack-level efficiency, and unlocking the right features to support our next chapter. Dropbox seventh-generation hardware A look under the hood of our next-gen hardware Performance Maximizing system throughput at the server and rack level Reducing latency of individual processes Improving price-performance for Dropbox workloads Ensuring balanced I/O and memory bandwidth¬† We ran tests using SPECintrate (a benchmark for multi-threaded workloads) and compared how each chip stacked up in performance per watt and per core. The CPU we picked stood out for both high throughput and strong per-core performance. It outperformed the previous generation by 40%. Legend: Red dot indicates processor selected Moving from our sixth-generation Cartman platform to the new Crush platform marked a big jump in compute power. At the heart of that upgrade was a shift from the 48-core AMD EPYC 7642 ‚ÄúRome‚Äù processor to the 84-core AMD EPYC 9634 ‚ÄúGenoa.‚Äù This shift delivered some big gains: 75% more cores per socket (48 cores ‚Üí 84 cores), improving bin packing for containerized services 2x the memory capacity (256GB ‚Üí 512GB), boosting memory-heavy workloads DDR4 ‚Üí DDR5, delivering higher bandwidth¬† 25Gb ‚Üí 100Gb networking, aligning with growing internal traffic NVMe gen5, speeding up local disk access and system boot times We did all of this while keeping the same compact 1U ‚Äúpizza box‚Äù server design, allowing 46 servers per rack, with no extra space needed. Databases On the database side, we focused on boosting CPU performance. While our new Dexter platform keeps the same number of cores as the previous generation, it packs a punch with 30% more instructions per cycle (IPC) and an increased base frequency (from 2.1GHz to 3.25GHz). The shift from dual-socket to single-socket design also reduced delays from inter-socket communication. These upgrades led to up to 3.57x less replication lag‚Äîthe delay between when data is written to a primary system and when it‚Äôs copied to a secondary one‚Äîwhich made a huge difference for high-demand workloads like Dynovault and Edgestore. Early on, we realized our database and compute platforms had a lot in common when it came to requirements. That opened the door for us to use the same platform from our system vendor for both. Consolidating like this helped us simplify our support stack, making it easier to manage components, firmware, drivers, and OS updates. The result was a versatile, dual-use platform that removed key scaling bottlenecks without sacrificing density or efficiency. Storage Finally, on the storage front, our design goals evolved to keep pace with increasing drive capacities. As drives get bigger‚Äîsome now hold over 30TB‚Äîwe had to think ahead. One of our internal performance standards is 30Gbps per PB of data. But with future systems expected to push past 100Gbps, we aimed even higher: 200Gbps throughput.¬† We also reworked our SAS topology to evenly allocate bandwidth to each drive and provide total system bandwidth past 200Gbps. And since this scale demanded stronger networking, we teamed up with our network engineering team to design a new 400G-ready data center architecture. Thermal and power architecture Upgrading to higher-core CPUs meant we had to rethink our approach to thermal and power management. Across the board, we saw power demands rise, so we needed a smarter way to stay within the limits of our existing data center infrastructure. First, we set a cap on processor thermal design power (TDP) to make sure we could pack in as many cores per rack as possible without blowing past our cooling or power budget. Rather than taking worst-case ‚Äúnameplate‚Äù power measurements‚Äîmanufacturer-listed maximums that often overestimate real usage‚Äîwe modeled real-world system usage. The models showed our servers could draw over 16kW per cabinet, which would‚Äôve been a dealbreaker under our old 15kW per-rack power budget. To make it work without overhauling our entire power infrastructure, we teamed up with our data center engineering team and made a major change: We switched from two PDUs to four PDUs per rack, using existing busways and adding more receptacles. Seventh-generation compute and storage (left); quad PDUs to meet higher power requirements (right) This move effectively doubled our available rack power, giving us the breathing room to support current loads‚Äîand even future accelerator cards. Finally, we also worked closely with suppliers to improve airflow, upgrade heatsink designs, optimize fan curves, and test thermals under full-load conditions. It was a full-stack effort to keep things cool and efficient. Focus on storage Our storage strategy is all about getting more out of the same physical space. We‚Äôve steadily increased the capacity of our traditional 3.5‚Äù hard drives from around 14TB to over 30TB in just a few years. This density improvement brings benefits: For one, it lowers cost per terabyte‚Äîand also reduces power usage per terabyte. However, higher densities also heighten sensitivity to acoustic and vibrational interference. And for Dropbox, since over 99% of our storage fleet uses shingled magnetic recording (SMR) technology‚Äîwhich packs data in even tighter‚Äîthe margin for error is razor-thin. Dropbox continues to leap up to the next available areal density curve Here‚Äôs the challenge: the read/write head inside these drives operates with nanometer precision. Even a tiny vibration can knock it off track. And when you‚Äôve got fans spinning at over 10,000 RPM to cool a dense server, vibrations (and noise) can quickly stack up. That leads to something called a position error signal (PES)‚Äîand, in the worst case, a write fault that forces the drive to retry. That slows things down, increasing latency and reducing IOPS. At the same time, we need that airflow to keep the drives cool. They operate best at around 40¬∞C‚Äîand if things get too hot, drives age faster and error rates rise. This means we‚Äôre constantly balancing two opposing forces: cool enough to perform, quiet enough to be precise. To solve this, we co-developed our next-gen storage chassis with the system and drive suppliers. The key features we focused on were: Vibration control: Acoustical isolation and damping¬† Thermals: Improved fan control and airflow redirection¬† Future-proofing: Compatibility with the next generation of large-capacity drives Redirecting high-velocity air to augment cooling That work paid off. We were one of the first to adopt Western Digital‚Äôs Ultrastar HC690, which provides up to a 32TB SMR drive that fits 11 platters into a standard 3.5‚Äù casing. That‚Äôs more than a 10% bump in capacity compared to the last generation.¬† Leveling up with GPUs To support Dash, our universal search and knowledge management product, it was clear we needed to bring GPUs into the mix. Features like intelligent previews, document understanding, fast search, and video processing (plus more recent work with large language models) all require serious computing muscle.¬† These workloads demand high parallelism, massive memory bandwidth, and low-latency interconnects‚Äîrequirements that traditional CPU-based servers can‚Äôt economically support. So as part of our seventh-generation hardware rollout, we introduced two new GPU-enabled server tiers: Gumby and Godzilla. GPU generations Gumby builds on our Crush compute platform but adds support for a wide range of GPU accelerators‚Äîhence the flexible name. It‚Äôs designed for flexibility, with support for TDPs ranging from 75W to 600W as well as both half-height half-length (HHHL) and full-height full-length (FHFL) PCIe form factors. Gumby is optimized for lightweight inference tasks like video transcoding, embedding generation, and other service-side machine learning enhancements. Godzilla is built for big jobs. It supports up to 8 interconnected GPUs, delivering the performance required for LLM testing, fine-tuning, and other high-throughput machine learning workflows. Together, Gumby and Godzilla allow Dropbox to scale AI across our products while maintaining control over performance, cost, and energy efficiency. Across compute, storage, and accelerators, we pushed performance while staying true to our principles: build right-sized, cost-efficient, and optimized systems tailored to our needs. This isn‚Äôt just next-gen tech‚Äîit‚Äôs hardware shaped by how Dropbox actually works. What we learned along the way Thermals and power are the new bottlenecks No matter where we looked‚Äîcompute, storage, or GPU platforms‚Äîone thing was clear: power demands are going up. To keep performance scaling, we had to rethink everything from airflow patterns to how power gets delivered at the rack level. That‚Äôs what led us to move from two to four PDUs per rack. The result? We can now support more power-hungry, high-density systems without compromising stability or performance. And while overall rack power increased, power consumption per petabyte and per core decreased, helping us stay on track with our sustainability goals. Supplier collaboration accelerates innovation Some of our biggest hardware wins came from teaming up early with suppliers. Whether it was redesigning hard drive acoustics, fine-tuning chassis layouts, or getting early access to cutting-edge components, collaboration made a huge difference. Instead of waiting for off-the-shelf solutions, we co-developed hardware that fits our needs‚Äîlike vibration-optimized storage enclosures and systems that are ready for the next generation of storage technology. Taking a product-first approach pays off The GPU tier is a prime example of where hardware strategy followed software needs. As AI-powered tools like Dash came online, we engaged early with our machine learning and video teams to understand what was needed. That early input helped us build platforms designed specifically for inference, video processing, and hosting large language models. This product-first mindset ensured the infrastructure was ready the moment the software needed it. Conclusion With our seventh-generation rollout, we‚Äôve made our in-house server hardware more strategically valuable than ever. Our latest Crush and Dexter platforms are powered by cutting-edge CPUs that give us a big lift in performance‚Äîespecially when it comes to IPC and transaction speed. On the storage side, we worked closely with vendors to develop Sonic, a new system that supports higher capacities. And as demand for AI products continues to grow, we introduced a dedicated hardware tier built specifically for these workloads.¬† Looking ahead, we‚Äôre already gearing up for the next wave of infrastructure change. Technologies like heat-assisted magnetic recording (HAMR) promise huge capacity gains, and they‚Äôll require us to get even more precise with acoustic and thermal management. Similarly, liquid cooling is transitioning from niche to necessity as compute densities continue to climb. This generation of infrastructure isn‚Äôt just about meeting today‚Äôs challenges‚Äîit‚Äôs a launchpad for what‚Äôs next. We‚Äôve built tightly integrated platforms optimized for Dropbox, strengthened our supplier partnerships, and created the flexibility to keep evolving. The next generation is already underway. Special thanks to Jesse Lee and Refugio¬†Fernandez,¬†who also contributed to this story. ~ ~ ~ If building innovative products, experiences, and infrastructure excites you, come build the future with us! Visit dropbox.com/jobs to see our open roles, and follow @LifeInsideDropbox on Instagram and Facebook to see what it's like to create a more enlightened way of working.

posts.author: Ïñ¥Îñ§Ïò§ÌõÑÏùò ÌîÑÎ¶¨Ïõ®Ïñ¥ Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞
posts.content:
AIÏôÄ Ìï®Íªò Ïä§ÎßàÌä∏Ìïú Ï£ºÏãù Ìà¨ÏûêÎ•º! Î≥µÏû°Ìïú Ï¶ùÍ∂åÏÇ¨ Î¶¨Ìè¨Ìä∏ÏôÄ Ï∞®Ìä∏ Î∂ÑÏÑù, Ïù¥Ï†ú AIÍ∞Ä Îπ†Î•¥Í≥† Ï†ïÌôïÌïòÍ≤å ÎèÑÏôÄÎìúÎ¶ΩÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥ Í∏ÄÏùÑ ÌÜµÌï¥ AI Í∏∞Î∞ò Ï£ºÏãù Î∂ÑÏÑùÏùò Î™®Îì† Í≤ÉÏùÑ ÌååÌó§ÏπòÍ≥†, Ïó¨Îü¨Î∂ÑÏùò Ìà¨Ïûê ÏÑ±Í≥µ ÌôïÎ•†ÏùÑ ÎÜíÏù¥Îäî ÎπÑÎ≤ïÏùÑ Í≥µÍ∞úÌï©ÎãàÎã§!

 

ÌòπÏãú Ï£ºÏãù Ìà¨Ïûê ÌïòÏãúÎ©¥ÏÑú Î∞©ÎåÄÌïú Ï†ïÎ≥¥Ïùò Î∞îÎã§ÏóêÏÑú Í∏∏ÏùÑ ÏûÉÏóàÎçò Í≤ΩÌóò ÏûàÏúºÏã†Í∞ÄÏöî? ÏàòÏã≠ ÌéòÏù¥ÏßÄÏßúÎ¶¨ Ï¶ùÍ∂åÏÇ¨ Î¶¨Ìè¨Ìä∏Î•º ÏùΩÎã§Í∞Ä ÏßÄÏ≥êÎ≤ÑÎ¶¨Í±∞ÎÇò, Î≥µÏû°Ìïú Ï∞®Ìä∏ ÏïûÏóêÏÑú Î©çÌïòÎãà ÏÑú ÏûàÏóàÎçò Ï†ÅÏùÄÏöî? Ï†úÍ∞Ä ÏÜîÏßÅÌûà ÎßêÌï¥ÏÑú Í∑∏Îû¨Í±∞Îì†Ïöî. Í∑∏Îü∞Îç∞ ÎßêÏù¥Ï£†, Ïù¥Ï†úÎäî Í∑∏Îü¥ ÌïÑÏöîÍ∞Ä ÏóÜÏñ¥Ï°åÏñ¥Ïöî! AIÍ∞Ä Ïù¥ Î™®Îì† Í≥ºÏ†ïÏùÑ ÌòÅÏã†Ï†ÅÏúºÎ°ú Î∞îÍøîÎÜìÍ≥† ÏûàÎãµÎãàÎã§. Ïò§Îäò Ïö∞Î¶¨Îäî Ï¶ùÍ∂åÏÇ¨ Î¶¨Ìè¨Ìä∏ÏôÄ Ï£ºÏãù Ï∞®Ìä∏Î•º AIÍ∞Ä Ïñ¥ÎñªÍ≤å Î∂ÑÏÑùÌïòÍ≥†, Ïó¨Îü¨Î∂ÑÏùò Ìà¨Ïûê ÏùòÏÇ¨Í≤∞Ï†ïÏóê ÏñºÎßàÎÇò ÌÅ∞ ÎèÑÏõÄÏùÑ Ï§Ñ Ïàò ÏûàÎäîÏßÄ ÏïåÏïÑÎ≥º Í±∞ÏòàÏöî. ÏßÑÏßú ÎÜÄÎùºÏö¥ Î≥ÄÌôîÍ∞Ä Ï∞æÏïÑÏôîÎã§Îäî Í±∏ ÎäêÎÅºÏã§ Í≤ÅÎãàÎã§!

 

Ï£ºÏãù Ï†ïÎ≥¥ Í≤ÄÏÉâ, Ïôú AIÍ∞Ä ÎåÄÏÑ∏ÏùºÍπå?

ÏµúÍ∑º ÎØ∏Íµ≠Ïùò Ïõπ Ï°∞ÏÇ¨ Ï†ÑÎ¨∏ÏóÖÏ≤¥ ÏãúÎ∞ÄÎü¨ÏõπÏùò Î∞úÌëúÏóê Îî∞Î•¥Î©¥, Ï±óGPT ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÏûêÏùò Îâ¥Ïä§ Í¥ÄÎ†® Í≤ÄÏÉâÏù¥ ÏûëÎÖÑ 1Ïõî ÎåÄÎπÑ Î¨¥Î†§ 212%ÎÇò Í∏âÏ¶ùÌñàÎã§Í≥† Ìï¥Ïöî. Ïó¨Í∏∞ÏÑú Í∞ÄÏû• ÎààÏóê ÎùÑÎäî Î∂ÄÎ∂ÑÏùÄ, Í≤ÄÏÉâÎêòÎäî Îâ¥Ïä§ Ïπ¥ÌÖåÍ≥†Î¶¨ Ï§ë Ï£ºÏãùÍ≥º Í∏àÏúµ Í¥ÄÎ†® Ï†ïÎ≥¥Í∞Ä Í∞ÅÍ∞Å 33%, 21%Î°ú Ï†àÎ∞ò Ïù¥ÏÉÅÏùÑ Ï∞®ÏßÄÌïúÎã§Îäî Ï†êÏûÖÎãàÎã§.

Ïù¥ ÌÜµÍ≥ÑÎäî Îã®ÏàúÌûà Îâ¥Ïä§Î•º Ï∞æÎäî Í≤ÉÏùÑ ÎÑòÏñ¥, "Ïù¥ Îâ¥Ïä§Í∞Ä Ï£ºÍ∞ÄÏóê Ïñ¥Îñ§ ÏòÅÌñ•ÏùÑ Ï§ÑÍπå?", "Ï∞®Ìä∏ÏóêÏÑú Ïñ¥Îñ§ Ïã†Ìò∏Í∞Ä ÎÇòÌÉÄÎÇòÎäî Í±∏Íπå?"Ï≤òÎüº Î≥¥Îã§ Ïã¨Ï∏µÏ†ÅÏù∏ Î∂ÑÏÑùÏùÑ AIÏóêÍ≤å ÏöîÍµ¨ÌïòÎäî Ìà¨ÏûêÏûêÎì§Ïù¥ ÎäòÍ≥† ÏûàÎã§Îäî ÏùòÎØ∏ÏòàÏöî. ÏïÑÏßÅ ÎåÄÎ∂ÄÎ∂ÑÏùò AIÎäî Îã®Ìé∏Ï†ÅÏù∏ Ï†ïÎ≥¥ Ï†úÍ≥µÏóê Í∑∏ÏπòÏßÄÎßå, Ìà¨ÏûêÏûêÎì§ÏùÄ Ïù¥ÎØ∏ AIÏùò Ïû†Ïû¨Î†•ÏùÑ Î≥¥Í≥† ÏûàÎäî Í±∞Ï£†.

ÏïåÏïÑÎëêÏÑ∏Ïöî!
AIÎäî ÌéÄÎçîÎ©òÌÉà Î∂ÑÏÑùÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ Í∏∞Ïà†Ï†Å Î∂ÑÏÑù, ÎßûÏ∂§ Ï†ÑÎûµ Ï†úÏïàÍπåÏßÄ Ï£ºÏãù Ìà¨ÏûêÏóê ÌïÑÏöîÌïú Î≥µÏû°Ìïú ÏûëÏóÖÏùÑ Ìö®Ïú®Ï†ÅÏúºÎ°ú ÎèÑÏôÄÏ§Ñ Ïàò ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§.

 

Íµ¨Í∏Ä Ï†úÎØ∏ÎÇòÏù¥Í∞Ä Ï£ºÏãù Î∂ÑÏÑùÏóê ÌäπÌûà Ïú†Î¶¨Ìïú Ïù¥Ïú†

Ïù¥Îü∞ ÏÉÅÌô©ÏóêÏÑú Íµ¨Í∏ÄÏùò Ï†úÎØ∏ÎÇòÏù¥Í∞Ä Ï£ºÏãù Ï†ïÎ≥¥ Î∂ÑÏÑùÏóê Îçî Ïú†Î¶¨Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÎã§Îäî Ï†êÏùÑ Í∞ÑÍ≥ºÌï† Ïàò ÏóÜÏñ¥Ïöî.   ÌòÑÎåÄ ÏÇ¨ÌöåÏóêÏÑú Ïä§ÎßàÌä∏Ìè∞ÏùÄ Îã®ÏàúÌïú ÏÜåÌÜµ ÎèÑÍµ¨Î•º ÎÑòÏñ¥, Ïö∞Î¶¨ ÏÇ∂Ïùò Ï§ëÏã¨ÏóêÏÑú Í∞úÏù∏ ÎπÑÏÑú Ïó≠Ìï†ÏùÑ ÌÜ°ÌÜ°Ìûà ÌïòÍ≥† ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† Í∑∏ ÌïµÏã¨ÏóêÎäî Î∞îÎ°ú 'Ïù∏Í≥µÏßÄÎä• Ïñ¥ÏãúÏä§ÌÑ¥Ìä∏'Í∞Ä ÏûêÎ¶¨ Ïû°Í≥† ÏûàÏ£†. Í∑∏Îü∞Îç∞ ÏãúÏ§ëÏóê ÏõåÎÇô Îã§ÏñëÌïú AI Ïñ¥ÏãúÏä§ÌÑ¥Ìä∏Îì§Ïù¥ ÎßéÎã§ Î≥¥Îãà, Ïñ¥Îñ§ Í≤ÉÏùÑ ÏÑ†ÌÉùÌï¥Ïïº Ìï†ÏßÄ Í≥†ÎØºÏù¥ ÎêòÏã§ Í±∞ÏòàÏöî. Í∑∏ÎûòÏÑú Ï†úÍ∞Ä ÏßÅÏ†ë ÏïàÎìúÎ°úÏù¥Îìú Í∏∞Î∞òÏùò ÎåÄÌëúÏ†ÅÏù∏ ÎÑ§ Í∞ÄÏßÄ AI Ïñ¥ÏãúÏä§ÌÑ¥Ìä∏, Ï¶â Bixby, ChatGPT, Perplexity, Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† GeminiÎ•º Ïã¨Ï∏µÏ†ÅÏúºÎ°ú ÏÇ¨Ïö©Ìï¥Î≥¥Î©∞ Í∞ÅÏûêÏùò Ïû•Îã®Ï†êÏùÑ Î∂ÑÏÑùÌï¥Î¥§ÏäµÎãàÎã§. Í≥ºÏó∞ Ïñ¥Îñ§ Ïñ¥ÏãúÏä§ÌÑ¥Ìä∏Í∞Ä ÎãπÏã†Ïùò ÏùºÏÉÅÏóê ÏßÑÏ†ïÌïú 'ÎÇ¥ ÏÇ¨Îûå'Ïù¥ Îê† Ïàò ÏûàÏùÑÍπåÏöî?

 

Bixby: ÏÇºÏÑ± Í∏∞Í∏∞ ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÏûêÎßåÏùÑ ÏúÑÌïú ÎßûÏ∂§Ìòï Ï°∞Î†•Ïûê

ÏÇºÏÑ± Í∞§Îü≠Ïãú Ïä§ÎßàÌä∏Ìè∞Ïóê Í∏∞Î≥∏Ï†ÅÏúºÎ°ú ÌÉëÏû¨ÎêòÏñ¥ ÏûàÎäî BixbyÎäî Ï¢ÖÏ¢Ö Í∑∏ Ïû†Ïû¨Î†•ÏùÑ Í∞ÑÍ≥ºÌïòÍ∏∞ ÏâΩÏäµÎãàÎã§. Ï†Ä ÎòêÌïú Ï≤òÏùåÏóêÎäî Îã®ÏàúÌïú ÏùåÏÑ± Î™ÖÎ†π Í∏∞Îä• Ï†ïÎèÑÎ°úÎßå Ïó¨Í≤ºÏ£†. ÌïòÏßÄÎßå ÏßÅÏ†ë ÏãúÍ∞ÑÏùÑ Ìà¨ÏûêÌïòÏó¨ ÏÇ¨Ïö©Ìï¥Î≥¥Îãà ÏòàÏÉÅÎ≥¥Îã§ Ìõ®Ïî¨ Í∞ïÎ†•Ìïú Í∏∞Í∏∞ ÌÜµÌï© Îä•Î†•ÏùÑ ÏßÄÎÖîÎã§Îäî Í≤ÉÏùÑ Íπ®Îã¨ÏïòÏäµÎãàÎã§. Ï†ú Galaxy A72ÏóêÏÑú ÌÖåÏä§Ìä∏ÌñàÏùÑ Îïå, ÏÑ§Ï†ï Î≥ÄÍ≤Ω, Ïï± Ïã§Ìñâ, SmartThings Í∏∞Í∏∞ Ï†úÏñ¥ Îì± Ïä§ÎßàÌä∏Ìè∞ ÏãúÏä§ÌÖú Ï†ÑÎ∞òÍ≥ºÏùò Ïó∞ÎèôÏÑ±Ïù¥ Îß§Ïö∞ Îõ∞Ïñ¥ÎÇ¨ÏäµÎãàÎã§.

Ï£ºÎ™©Ìï† ÎßåÌïú Í∏∞Îä•!
"Hi Bixby"ÏôÄ Í∞ôÏùÄ Ìò∏Ï∂úÏñ¥(wake word)Î•º ÌÜµÌï¥ Ìï∏Ï¶àÌîÑÎ¶¨Î°ú Ïã§ÌñâÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÎã§Îäî Ï†êÏùÄ ÏùºÏÉÅÏÉùÌôú ÏÜçÏóêÏÑú ÏÉÅÎãπÌïú Ìé∏Î¶¨Ìï®ÏùÑ Ï†úÍ≥µÌï©ÎãàÎã§. ÏòàÎ•º Îì§Ïñ¥, "ÏïºÍ∞Ñ Ïπ¥Î©îÎùº Î™®Îìú Ïó¥Ïñ¥Ï§ò"ÎùºÍ≥† ÎßêÌïòÎ©¥ Ìï¥Îãπ Ïπ¥Î©îÎùº Ïï±ÏùÑ Ï¶âÏãú Ïã§ÌñâÌïòÍ≥†, Ïã¨ÏßÄÏñ¥ Ïû•ÎÖ∏Ï∂ú Ï¥¨ÏòÅ ÏÑ§Ï†ïÍπåÏßÄ ÏïàÎÇ¥Ìï¥Ï£ºÎäî Îì± Ïã§ÏßàÏ†ÅÏù∏ ÏûëÏóÖ ÏàòÌñâÏùÑ ÎèïÎäî Îä•Î†•Ïù¥ ÌÉÅÏõîÌñàÏäµÎãàÎã§.

 

Í∑∏Îü¨ÎÇò ÏÇºÏÑ± Ïï± ÏÉùÌÉúÍ≥ÑÎ•º Î≤óÏñ¥ÎÇú ÏòÅÏó≠ÏóêÏÑúÎäî Í∑∏ ÌïúÍ≥ÑÍ∞Ä Î™ÖÌôïÌïòÍ≤å ÎìúÎü¨ÎÇ¨ÏäµÎãàÎã§. Î≥µÏû°Ìïú Ï†ïÎ≥¥ ÏßàÏùòÎÇò Í∞úÎ∞©Ìòï ÎåÄÌôîÏóêÏÑúÎäî Îã§Î•∏ Î≤îÏö© AI Ïñ¥ÏãúÏä§ÌÑ¥Ìä∏Îì§Ïóê ÎπÑÌï¥ Îã§ÏÜå ÏïΩÌïú Î™®ÏäµÏùÑ Î≥¥ÏòÄÏäµÎãàÎã§. Ïó¨Ï†ÑÌûà 'Î™ÖÎ†π Ï§ëÏã¨'Ïùò Ïù∏Í≥µÏßÄÎä•Ïù¥ÎùºÎäî Ï†êÏóêÏÑú, Ïú†Ïó∞Ìïú ÎåÄÌôîÎ•º ÌÜµÌïú Ï†ïÎ≥¥ ÌÉêÏÉâÎ≥¥Îã§Îäî ÌäπÏ†ï Í∏∞Îä• Ïã§ÌñâÏóê ÏµúÏ†ÅÌôîÎêòÏñ¥ ÏûàÎã§Í≥† Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§.

‚ö†Ô∏è Bixby ÏÇ¨Ïö© Ïãú Ïú†ÏùòÏ†ê!
BixbyÎäî ÏÇºÏÑ± Í∏∞Í∏∞ Î∞è SmartThings ÏÉùÌÉúÍ≥ÑÏóê ÍπäÏù¥ Ïó∞ÎèôÎêòÏñ¥ ÏûàÏñ¥ Ïù¥ Ïô∏Ïùò ÏÇ¨Ïö© ÌôòÍ≤ΩÏóêÏÑúÎäî Í∏∞Îä•Ïù¥ Ï†úÌïúÏ†ÅÏùº Ïàò ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§.

 

ChatGPT: Ïñ∏Ïñ¥ ÏßÄÎä•ÏùÄ ÏµúÍ∞ï, Í∑∏Îü¨ÎÇò ÏÜêÏù¥ Í∞ÄÎäî AI

ChatGPTÎäî Î™ÖÌôïÌïòÍ≤å ÎßêÌï¥, Ïä§ÎßàÌä∏Ìè∞ Í∏∞Í∏∞ Ï†úÏñ¥Î≥¥Îã§Îäî Ïñ∏Ïñ¥ Ïù¥Ìï¥ Î∞è ÏÉùÏÑ± Îä•Î†•Ïóê ÌäπÌôîÎêú Ïñ¥ÏãúÏä§ÌÑ¥Ìä∏ÏûÖÎãàÎã§. Î≥µÏû°Ìïú ÏßàÎ¨∏ÏóêÎèÑ Îß•ÎùΩÏùÑ Ï†ïÌôïÌûà ÌååÏïÖÌïòÏó¨ ÎãµÎ≥ÄÌïòÍ≥†, ÌõÑÏÜç ÏßàÎ¨∏ÏóêÎèÑ Îä•ÏàòÎä•ÎûÄÌïòÍ≤å ÎåÄÏùëÌïòÎäî Î™®ÏäµÏùÄ Í∞ÄÌûà ÎèÖÎ≥¥Ï†ÅÏûÖÎãàÎã§. Ï∞ΩÏùòÏ†ÅÏù∏ ÏïÑÏù¥ÎîîÏñ¥ Íµ¨ÏÉÅ, Í∏ÄÏì∞Í∏∞ Î≥¥Ï°∞, Í∏¥ ÌÖçÏä§Ìä∏ ÏöîÏïΩ Îì± Ïñ∏Ïñ¥ Í∏∞Î∞ò ÏûëÏóÖÏóêÏÑúÎäî ÏµúÍ∞ïÏùò Îä•Î†•ÏùÑ Î≥¥Ïó¨Ï§çÎãàÎã§.

ÌïòÏßÄÎßå Ïä§ÎßàÌä∏Ìè∞ Ïö¥ÏòÅÏ≤¥Ï†ú(OS)ÏôÄÏùò Ïó∞ÎèôÏÑ± Ï∏°Î©¥ÏóêÏÑúÎäî ÌïúÍ≥ÑÍ∞Ä Î™ÖÌôïÌïòÍ≤å ÎìúÎü¨ÎÇ¨ÏäµÎãàÎã§. Ìò∏Ï∂úÏñ¥(wake word)Í∞Ä ÏóÜÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïóê ÏùåÏÑ±ÎßåÏúºÎ°úÎäî Ïñ¥ÏãúÏä§ÌÑ¥Ìä∏Î•º Ïã§ÌñâÌï† Ïàò ÏóÜÏúºÎ©∞, ÏàòÎèôÏúºÎ°ú Ïï±ÏùÑ Ïó¥Ïñ¥Ïïº ÌïòÎäî Î≤àÍ±∞Î°úÏõÄÏù¥ ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§. ÎòêÌïú, Wi-Fi ÎÅÑÍ∏∞ÎÇò ÏùºÏ†ï ÌôïÏù∏Í≥º Í∞ôÏùÄ OSÏôÄ ÏßÅÏ†ë Ïó∞ÎèôÎêú Ïä§ÎßàÌä∏Ìè∞ Í∏∞Îä•ÏùÄ ChatGPTÍ∞Ä ÏßÅÏ†ë Ï†úÏñ¥ÌïòÍ∏∞ Ïñ¥Î†µÏäµÎãàÎã§. ÏòàÎ•º Îì§Ïñ¥, "Wi-Fi Í∫ºÏ§ò"ÎùºÍ≥† Î™ÖÎ†πÌïòÎ©¥, Ïã§Ï†úÎ°ú Wi-FiÎ•º ÎÅÑÎäî ÎåÄÏã† Í∑∏ Î∞©Î≤ïÏùÑ ÏÑ§Î™ÖÌï¥Ï£ºÎäî ÏãùÏûÖÎãàÎã§. ÏùåÏÑ±ÏúºÎ°ú Ï†ÑÎã¨Î∞õÏùÄ Í≤∞Í≥ºÎèÑ ÎåÄÎ∂ÄÎ∂Ñ ChatGPT Ïï± ÎÇ¥Î∂ÄÏóêÏÑúÎßå ÌôïÏù∏Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÏñ¥, Îã§Î•∏ Ïñ¥ÏãúÏä§ÌÑ¥Ìä∏Îì§Ï≤òÎüº 'Ï¶âÍ∞ÅÏ†ÅÏúºÎ°ú ÌôîÎ©¥Ïóê Î∞òÏùëÌïòÎäî' Í≤ΩÌóòÏùÑ Í∏∞ÎåÄÌïòÍ∏¥ Ïñ¥Î†µÏäµÎãàÎã§.

‚úÖ Í∞ïÏ†ê: ÎåÄÌôîÌòï ÏßÄÎä•, Ï∞ΩÏùòÏ†Å ÏÇ¨Í≥†, ÌÖçÏä§Ìä∏ ÏûëÏóÖÏóê ÏïïÎèÑÏ†ÅÏù∏ Í∞ïÏ†ê.
‚ùå ÏïΩÏ†ê: ÏùåÏÑ± Ìò∏Ï∂ú ÎØ∏ÏßÄÏõê, Ïä§ÎßàÌä∏Ìè∞ Í∏∞Î≥∏ Í∏∞Îä• Ï†úÏñ¥Ïùò Ïñ¥Î†§ÏõÄ, Ï†úÌïúÏ†ÅÏù∏ Ïï± Ïó∞ÎèôÏÑ±.

 

Perplexity: Ïà®Í≤®ÏßÑ Î©ÄÌã∞ÌÉúÏä§ÌÇπ Í∞ïÏûê, ÏßÄÎä•Ìòï Ï†ïÎ≥¥ ÌÉêÏÉâÍ∞Ä

PerplexityÎäî ChatGPTÎßåÌÅº ÎåÄÏ§ëÏ†ÅÏù∏ Ïù∏ÏßÄÎèÑÎäî ÏóÜÏßÄÎßå, Ïã§Ï†ú ÏÇ¨Ïö© ÌôòÍ≤ΩÏóêÏÑúÎäî ÎÜÄÎùºÏö¥ Í≤ΩÏüÅÎ†•ÏùÑ Î≥¥Ïó¨Ï£ºÏóàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Í∞ÄÏû• Ïù∏ÏÉÅ ÍπäÏóàÎçò Ï†êÏùÄ ÏßàÎ¨∏Ïùò ÌùêÎ¶ÑÏùÑ ÏûêÏó∞Ïä§ÎüΩÍ≤å Ïù¥Ïñ¥Í∞ÄÎ©∞ Ï≤òÎ¶¨ÌïòÎäî Îä•Î†•Í≥º Îã§ÏñëÌïú Ïï±Í≥ºÏùò Ïó∞ÎèôÏÑ±Ïù¥ÏóàÏäµÎãàÎã§.

ÏòàÎ•º Îì§Ïñ¥, "Ï£ºÎ≥Ä ÎßõÏßë Ï∂îÏ≤úÌï¥Ï§ò"ÎùºÍ≥† ÏßàÎ¨∏Ìïú Îí§, "Í∑∏Îüº ÎèÑÎ≥¥ Í±∞Î¶¨Ïóê ÏûàÎäî Í≥≥ÏúºÎ°úÎßå Ï¢ÅÌòÄÏ§ò", Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† ÎßàÏßÄÎßâÏúºÎ°ú "ÏÑ†ÌÉùÌïú ÏãùÎãπ Ï†ïÎ≥¥Î•º ÏπúÍµ¨ÏóêÍ≤å Î¨∏ÏûêÎ°ú Î≥¥ÎÇ¥Ï§ò"ÏôÄ Í∞ôÏùÄ Îã§Îã®Í≥Ñ ÏöîÏ≤≠ÏùÑ Ï§ëÍ∞ÑÏóê ÎÅäÍπÄ ÏóÜÏù¥ Ïú†Ïó∞ÌïòÍ≤å Ï≤òÎ¶¨Ìï¥ÎÉàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥Îäî PerplexityÍ∞Ä Îã®ÏàúÌïú ÏßàÎ¨∏-ÎãµÎ≥Ä AIÎ•º ÎÑòÏñ¥, ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÏûêÏùò Î≥µÌï©Ï†ÅÏù∏ ÏûëÏóÖ ÏßÄÏãúÎ•º Ïù¥Ìï¥ÌïòÍ≥† Ìï¥Í≤∞Ìï¥Ï£ºÎäî ÏßÑÏ†ïÌïú 'ÎèÑÏö∞ÎØ∏'Î°úÏÑúÏùò Í∞ïÏ†êÏùÑ Î≥¥Ïó¨Ï£ºÎäî ÏÇ¨Î°ÄÏûÖÎãàÎã§. ÎòêÌïú, Uber Ïã§Ìñâ Ïãú Î™©Ï†ÅÏßÄÎ•º ÏûêÎèôÏúºÎ°ú ÏûÖÎ†•Ìï¥Ï£ºÍ±∞ÎÇò, SpotifyÎ•º Ïã§ÌñâÌïòÏó¨ ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÏûêÍ∞Ä ÏõêÌïòÎäî ÏùåÏïÖÏùÑ Ïû¨ÏÉùÌïòÎäî Îì± Ïï± Ïó∞Îèô Í∏∞Îä•ÎèÑ Îß§Ïö∞ ÏõêÌôúÌïòÍ≤å ÏûëÎèôÌñàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥Ï≤òÎüº PerplexityÎäî Îã®Ïàú Í≤ÄÏÉâÏùÑ ÎÑòÏñ¥ Ïã§ÏÉùÌôú ÏûêÎèôÌôîÏóê Ìïú Î∞ú Îçî Îã§Í∞ÄÏÑ† ÎäêÎÇåÏù¥ÏóàÏäµÎãàÎã§.

‚úÖ Í∞ïÏ†ê: Î≥µÌï©Ï†ÅÏù∏ Îã§Îã®Í≥Ñ ÏûëÏóÖ Ï≤òÎ¶¨ Îä•Î†•, Îõ∞Ïñ¥ÎÇú Ïï± Ïó∞ÎèôÏÑ±, Ïã¨Ï∏µÏ†ÅÏù∏ Ï†ïÎ≥¥ ÌÉêÏÉâ Î∞è ÏöîÏïΩ Îä•Î†•.
‚ùå ÏïΩÏ†ê: ÏùåÏÑ± Ìò∏Ï∂úÏñ¥ ÎØ∏ÏßÄÏõêÏúºÎ°ú Ïù∏Ìïú Ìï∏Ï¶àÌîÑÎ¶¨ Ï†úÏñ¥ Î∂àÍ∞Ä, ÏÉÅÎåÄÏ†ÅÏúºÎ°ú ÎÇÆÏùÄ ÎåÄÏ§ëÏ†Å Ïù∏ÏßÄÎèÑÎ°ú Ïù∏Ìïú Ï∂îÍ∞Ä Í∏∞Îä• ÌôïÏû•ÏÑ± ÎØ∏ÏßÄÏàò.

 

Gemini: Íµ¨Í∏Ä ÏÉùÌÉúÍ≥ÑÏùò ÌïµÏã¨, Í∞ÄÏû• Í∑†Ìòï Ïû°Ìûå Ï∞®ÏÑ∏ÎåÄ ÎπÑÏÑú

Google AssistantÏùò ÏßÑÌôîÌòïÏù∏ GeminiÎäî Ï†úÍ∞Ä Ï≤¥ÌóòÌïú Ïñ¥ÏãúÏä§ÌÑ¥Ìä∏ Ï§ë Í∞ÄÏû• Í∑†Ìòï Ïû°Ìûå ÏÑ±Îä•ÏùÑ Î≥¥Ïó¨Ï£ºÏóàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Í∏∞Ï°¥ "Hey Google"Ïù¥ÎùºÎäî Ìò∏Ï∂úÏñ¥Í∞Ä Í∑∏ÎåÄÎ°ú Ïú†ÏßÄÎêòÏñ¥ Ìï∏Ï¶àÌîÑÎ¶¨ ÏÇ¨Ïö©Ïù¥ Í∞ÄÎä•ÌñàÏúºÎ©∞, Gmail, Google Keep, Google Calendar Îì± Íµ¨Í∏Ä ÏÑúÎπÑÏä§ Ï†ÑÎ∞òÍ≥ºÏùò ÌÜµÌï©Ïù¥ Îß§Ïö∞ Îõ∞Ïñ¥ÎÇ¨ÏäµÎãàÎã§.

ÏòàÎ•º Îì§Ïñ¥, "NathanÏù¥ Î≥¥ÎÇ∏ Ïù¥Î©îÏùº Î≥¥Ïó¨Ï§ò"ÎùºÍ≥† ÏöîÏ≤≠ÌïòÎ©¥ Ìï¥Îãπ Ïù¥Î©îÏùºÏùò ÌïµÏã¨ ÎÇ¥Ïö©ÏùÑ ÏöîÏïΩÌïòÏó¨ Ìôà ÌôîÎ©¥Ïóê Î∞îÎ°ú ÌëúÏãúÌï¥Ï£ºÎäî Îì±, Íµ¨Í∏Ä Ïï±Í≥ºÏùò Í∏¥Î∞ÄÌïú Ïó∞ÎèôÏù¥ ÎèãÎ≥¥ÏòÄÏäµÎãàÎã§. ÎòêÌïú, ÏùåÏÑ±ÏúºÎ°ú ÏáºÌïë Î™©Î°ùÏùÑ ÏöîÏ≤≠ÌïòÎ©¥ Google KeepÏóê ÏûêÎèôÏúºÎ°ú Ìï≠Î™©Îì§ÏùÑ Ï†ïÎ¶¨Ìï¥Ï£ºÎäî Í∏∞Îä•ÏùÄ Ïã§ÏßàÏ†ÅÏù∏ ÌôúÏö©ÎèÑ Î©¥ÏóêÏÑú Îß§Ïö∞ Í∞ïÎ†•ÌñàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥Îü¨Ìïú Ïó∞ÎèôÏÑ±Í≥º ÏûêÎèôÌôî Í∏∞Îä•ÏùÄ ÏùºÏÉÅÏÉùÌôúÏùò Ìö®Ïú®ÏÑ±ÏùÑ ÌÅ¨Í≤å ÎÜíÏó¨Ï£ºÏóàÏäµÎãàÎã§.

‚úÖ Í∞ïÏ†ê: ÏùåÏÑ± Ìò∏Ï∂úÏñ¥ ÏÇ¨Ïö© Í∞ÄÎä•, Íµ¨Í∏Ä Ïï± Î∞è ÏÑúÎπÑÏä§ÏôÄÏùò ÏôÑÎ≤ΩÌïòÍ≥† ÍπäÏùÄ Ïó∞Îèô, ÏûêÏó∞Ïñ¥ Ï≤òÎ¶¨ Îä•Î†• Ìñ•ÏÉÅ, Ï†ÑÎ∞òÏ†ÅÏúºÎ°ú Í∑†Ìòï Ïû°Ìûå Í∏∞Îä• Ï†úÍ≥µ.
‚ùå ÏïΩÏ†ê: Í∞ÑÌóêÏ†ÅÏúºÎ°ú ÏùëÎãµ ÏÜçÎèÑ Ï†ÄÌïò ÌòÑÏÉÅ Î∞úÏÉù, Î™®Îì† ÏöîÏ≤≠Ïóê ÎåÄÌïú ÏôÑÎ≤ΩÌïú Ïù¥Ìï¥ Î∂ÄÏ°± (Î∞úÏ†Ñ Ï§ë).

 

Ï¥ùÌèâ: ÎãπÏã†Ïùò AI Ïñ¥ÏãúÏä§ÌÑ¥Ìä∏, ÎàÑÍµ¨Î•º ÏÑ†ÌÉùÌïòÏãúÍ≤†ÏäµÎãàÍπå?

Ïù¥Î≤à ÎπÑÍµê Ï≤¥ÌóòÏùÑ ÌÜµÌï¥ ÎÑ§ Í∞ÄÏßÄ AI Ïñ¥ÏãúÏä§ÌÑ¥Ìä∏Í∞Ä Í∞ÅÍ∏∞ Îã§Î•∏ Í∞ïÏ†êÍ≥º ÏßÄÌñ•Ï†êÏùÑ Í∞ÄÏßÄÍ≥† ÏûàÎã§Îäî Í≤ÉÏùÑ Î™ÖÌôïÌûà Ïïå Ïàò ÏûàÏóàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Í≤∞Íµ≠ ÏµúÏ†ÅÏùò ÏÑ†ÌÉùÏùÄ ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÏûêÏùò Ï£ºÎêú Î™©Ï†ÅÍ≥º Ïä§ÎßàÌä∏Ìè∞ ÌôúÏö© Î∞©ÏãùÏóê Îî∞Îùº Îã¨ÎùºÏßà Í≤ÉÏûÖÎãàÎã§. ÏïÑÎûò ÌëúÎ•º ÌÜµÌï¥ ÎãπÏã†Ïùò AI Ïñ¥ÏãúÏä§ÌÑ¥Ìä∏ ÏÑ†ÌÉùÏóê ÎèÑÏõÄÏù¥ ÎêòÎäî Í∏∞Ï§ÄÏùÑ Ï†úÏãúÌï¥ ÎìúÎ¶ΩÎãàÎã§.

ÏÇ¨Ïö© Î™©Ï†Å Ï∂îÏ≤ú Ïñ¥ÏãúÏä§ÌÑ¥Ìä∏
ÏÇºÏÑ± Í∏∞Í∏∞ÏôÄÏùò ÍπäÏùÄ ÌÜµÌï© Î∞è Ï†úÏñ¥ Bixby
Ï∞ΩÏùòÏ†Å Í∏ÄÏì∞Í∏∞, Ï†ïÎ≥¥ ÏöîÏïΩ, Ïã¨Ï∏µ ÎåÄÌôî ChatGPT
Î≥µÌï©Ï†ÅÏù∏ Îã§Îã®Í≥Ñ ÏûëÏóÖ Ï≤òÎ¶¨, Îã§ÏñëÌïú Ïï± Ïó∞Îèô ÏûêÎèôÌôî Perplexity

ÏïÑÎ¨¥ÎèÑ ÎßêÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÎäî ÏµúÍ≥†Ïùò Î¨¥Î£å AI Ïù¥ÎØ∏ÏßÄ ÏÉùÏÑ±Í∏∞Î•º ÏïÑÏãúÎÇòÏöî? Firefly, DALL·E, MidjourneyÎäî ÏùµÏàôÌïòÏßÄÎßå, Google LabsÏóê Ï°∞Ïö©Ìûà Ïà®Ïñ¥ÏûàÎäî ÏßÑÏßú Í∞ïÎ†•Ìïú ÎèÑÍµ¨Í∞Ä ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Î∞îÎ°ú 'ImageFX'ÏûÖÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥ Í∏ÄÏóêÏÑú Í∑∏ ÎÜÄÎùºÏö¥ ÏÑ±Îä•Í≥º ÌôúÏö©Î≤ï, ÌîÑÎ°¨ÌîÑÌä∏ ÏòàÏãúÍπåÏßÄ Î™®Îëê ÌôïÏù∏Ìï¥Î≥¥ÏÑ∏Ïöî!

 

 Îã§ÏñëÌïú AI Ïù¥ÎØ∏ÏßÄ ÏÉùÏÑ±Í∏∞Î•º ÏÇ¨Ïö©Ìï¥ Î≥¥ÏÖ®ÏùÑ Í≤ÅÎãàÎã§. ÌôîÎ†§Ìïú Í∏∞Îä•Í≥º Í¥ëÍ≥† ÏÜçÏóêÏÑú Ïñ¥Îñ§ Í±∏ Ïç®Ïïº Ìï†ÏßÄ Í≥†ÎØºÎê† ÎïåÍ∞Ä ÎßéÏ£†. Ï†ÄÎèÑ Í∑∏Îû¨ÏúºÎãàÍπåÏöî. Í∑∏Îü∞Îç∞ ÏµúÍ∑ºÏóê Ïö∞Ïó∞Ìûà, ÎßàÏπò ÎπÑÎ∞Ä Ïó∞Íµ¨ÏÜåÏóê Ïà®Í≤®ÏßÑ Î≥¥Î¨ºÏ≤òÎüº Ï°∞Ïö©ÌïòÏßÄÎßå Í∞ïÎ†•Ìïú ÏÑ±Îä•ÏùÑ ÏûêÎûëÌïòÎäî ÎèÑÍµ¨Î•º Î∞úÍ≤¨ÌñàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Î∞îÎ°ú Íµ¨Í∏ÄÏùò ImageFXÏûÖÎãàÎã§. Í≥ºÎåÄÍ¥ëÍ≥† ÏóÜÏù¥, Ïò§ÏßÅ Í≤∞Í≥ºÎ¨ºÎ°úÎßå Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞ÌïòÎäî Ïù¥ ÎèÑÍµ¨Ïóê ÎåÄÌï¥ ÏÜîÏßÅÌïú ÌõÑÍ∏∞Î•º Í≥µÏú†Ìï¥ ÎìúÎ¶¥Í≤åÏöî.

 

Íµ¨Í∏ÄÏùò Ïà®Í≤®ÏßÑ Î≥¥ÏÑù, ImageFX ‚ú®

Íµ¨Í∏ÄÏù¥ AI Î∂ÑÏïºÏùò Í∞ïÏûêÎùºÎäî Í±¥ Î™®ÎëêÍ∞Ä ÏïÑÎäî ÏÇ¨Ïã§Ïù¥ÏßÄÎßå, Ïù¥ÏÉÅÌïòÍ≤åÎèÑ ImageFXÎäî Ï†ÑÎ©¥Ïóê ÎÇòÏÑúÏßÄ ÏïäÏäµÎãàÎã§. ÌïòÏßÄÎßå ÏùºÎã® ÏÇ¨Ïö©Ìï¥Î≥¥Î©¥, Ïôú Íµ¨Í∏ÄÏù¥ ÏûêÏã†Í∞êÏùÑ Í∞ÄÏ°åÎäîÏßÄ Ïïå Ïàò ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§.

ImageFXÎäî Íµ¨Í∏ÄÏùò ÏµúÏã† Î™®Îç∏Ïù∏ Imagen 3Î•º Í∏∞Î∞òÏúºÎ°ú ÏûëÎèôÌï©ÎãàÎã§. Îã§Î•∏ AIÎì§Ïù¥ ÌôîÎ†§ÌïòÍ≥† ÏòàÏà†Ï†ÅÏù∏ Ïä§ÌÉÄÏùºÏóê ÏßëÏ§ëÌï† Îïå, ImageFXÎäî 'ÏÇ¨Ïã§Í∞ê'Í≥º 'Ï†ïÌôïÏÑ±'Ïù¥ÎùºÎäî Í∏∞Î≥∏Ïóê Ï∂©Ïã§Ìï©ÎãàÎã§. ÎÜÄÎùºÏö¥ Ï†êÏùÄ Ïú†Î£å ÏöîÍ∏àÏ†úÎÇò Í¥ëÍ≥† ÏóÜÏù¥ Ïù¥ Î™®Îì† Í∏∞Îä•ÏùÑ Î¨¥Î£åÎ°ú Ï†úÍ≥µÌïúÎã§Îäî Í≤ÉÏù¥Ï£†.

 

ImageFX ÏãúÏûëÌïòÍ∏∞: 5Îã®Í≥Ñ ÏôÑÏ†Ñ Ï†ïÎ≥µ ‍

"Í∑∏ÎûòÏÑú Ïñ¥ÎñªÍ≤å ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÌïòÎäî Í±¥Îç∞?" ÌïòÍ≥† Í∂ÅÍ∏àÌï¥ÌïòÏã§ Î∂ÑÎì§ÏùÑ ÏúÑÌï¥ Ï§ÄÎπÑÌñàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Íµ¨Í∏Ä Í≥ÑÏ†ïÎßå ÏûàÎã§Î©¥ ÎàÑÍµ¨ÎÇò Îã® 5Îã®Í≥Ñ ÎßåÏóê Ï†ÑÎ¨∏Í∞Ä ÏàòÏ§ÄÏùò Ïù¥ÎØ∏ÏßÄÎ•º ÎßåÎì§ Ïàò ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§. ÏïÑÎûò Í∞ÄÏù¥ÎìúÎ•º Îî∞Îùº Ï∞®Í∑ºÏ∞®Í∑º ÏãúÏûëÌï¥Î≥¥ÏÑ∏Ïöî.

Îã®Í≥ÑÎ≥Ñ ImageFX ÏÇ¨Ïö© Í∞ÄÏù¥Îìú

  3. ÌîÑÎ°¨ÌîÑÌä∏ ÏûÖÎ†•: ÎßåÎì§Í≥† Ïã∂ÏùÄ Ïù¥ÎØ∏ÏßÄÏóê ÎåÄÌïú ÏÑ§Î™ÖÏùÑ ÌÖçÏä§Ìä∏ ÏûÖÎ†•Ï∞ΩÏóê ÏûêÏú†Î°≠Í≤å ÏûÖÎ†•Ìï©ÎãàÎã§. (Ïòà: "Ìï¥Î≥ÄÏóêÏÑú Ï±ÖÏùÑ ÏùΩÍ≥† ÏûàÎäî Í≥®Îì† Î¶¨Ìä∏Î¶¨Î≤Ñ") : ÏµúÏ†ÅÏùò Í≤∞Í≥ºÎ•º ÏúÑÌï¥ÏÑúÎäî ÏòÅÎ¨∏ ÌîÑÎ°¨ÌîÑÌä∏Î•º Í∂åÏû•Ìï©ÎãàÎã§.
  4. ÌîÑÎ°¨ÌîÑÌä∏ Ïπ©ÏúºÎ°ú Îã§Îì¨Í∏∞: ÌîÑÎ°¨ÌîÑÌä∏Î•º ÏûÖÎ†•ÌïòÎ©¥ ÌïòÎã®Ïóê [Cinematic], [35mm film], [Minimalist] Îì± Îã§ÏñëÌïú Ïä§ÌÉÄÏùºÏùò 'Ïπ©'Ïù¥ ÎÇòÌÉÄÎÇ©ÎãàÎã§. ÏõêÌïòÎäî Ïπ©ÏùÑ ÌÅ¥Î¶≠ÌïòÏó¨ Í≤∞Í≥ºÎ¨ºÏùÑ Îçî ÏÑ∏Î∞ÄÌïòÍ≤å Îã§Îì¨Ïñ¥ Î≥¥ÏÑ∏Ïöî.
  5. Í≤∞Í≥º ÌôïÏù∏ Î∞è Îã§Ïö¥Î°úÎìú: Ïû†Ïãú Í∏∞Îã§Î¶¨Î©¥ 4Í∞úÏùò Ïù¥ÎØ∏ÏßÄÍ∞Ä ÏÉùÏÑ±Îê©ÎãàÎã§. ÎßàÏùåÏóê ÎìúÎäî Ïù¥ÎØ∏ÏßÄÎ•º ÌÅ¥Î¶≠ÌïòÏó¨ Îçî ÌÅ¨Í≤å Î≥¥Í≥†, Îã§Ïö¥Î°úÎìú Î≤ÑÌäºÏùÑ ÎàåÎü¨ Ï†ÄÏû•ÌïòÎ©¥ ÎÅù!

 

ImageFX ÎßûÏ∂§ ÌîÑÎ°¨ÌîÑÌä∏, Ïù¥Î†áÍ≤å Ïç®Î≥¥ÏÑ∏Ïöî! ‚úçÔ∏è

ImageFXÏùò ÏßÑÏ†ïÌïú ÌûòÏùÄ 'ÌòÑÏã§ ÏÑ∏Í≥ÑÎ•º Î¨òÏÇ¨ÌïòÎäî' ÌîÑÎ°¨ÌîÑÌä∏ÏôÄ ÎßåÎÇ¨ÏùÑ Îïå Î∞úÌúòÎê©ÎãàÎã§. Ï∂îÏÉÅÏ†ÅÏù∏ Îã®Ïñ¥Î≥¥Îã§Îäî Íµ¨Ï≤¥Ï†ÅÏù∏ ÏÉÅÌô©, Ï°∞Î™Ö, Ïû¨ÏßàÏùÑ Î¨òÏÇ¨ÌïòÎ©¥ Ìõ®Ïî¨ Îçî ÏÇ¨Ïã§Ï†ÅÏù∏ Í≤∞Í≥ºÎ¨ºÏùÑ ÏñªÏùÑ Ïàò ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§. ÏïÑÎûò ÏòàÏãúÎì§ÏùÑ Ï∞∏Í≥†ÌïòÏó¨ Ïó¨Îü¨Î∂ÑÎßåÏùò ÌîÑÎ°¨ÌîÑÌä∏Î•º ÎßåÎì§Ïñ¥Î≥¥ÏÑ∏Ïöî.

Prompt: A macro photograph of a steaming cup of black coffee on a rustic wooden table. A single drop of condensation trickles down the side of the ceramic mug. hyper-realistic, high detail.

Ï±óGPT Ïû•Ïï† Î≥¥ÏÉÅ: Ïõî Íµ¨ÎèÖÎ£å 6.4% ÌôòÎ∂à, ÎãπÏã†ÎèÑ ÎåÄÏÉÅÏùºÍπåÏöî? ÏßÄÎÇúÎã¨ Ïò§ÌîàAI Ï±óGPT ÏÑúÎπÑÏä§ÏóêÏÑú Î∞úÏÉùÌïú ÏùºÏãú Ïò§Î•òÏóê ÎåÄÌïú Î≥¥ÏÉÅÏù¥ ÏãúÏûëÎêòÏóàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Í≥ºÏó∞ Ïñ¥Îñ§ Í∏∞Ï§ÄÏúºÎ°ú, ÏñºÎßàÎÇò ÌôòÎ∂àÎêòÎäîÏßÄ Í∂ÅÍ∏àÌïòÏãúÏ£†?

 

 ÌòπÏãú ÏßÄÎÇúÎã¨ Ï±óGPTÍ∞Ä Í∞ëÏûêÍ∏∞ Î®πÌÜµÏù¥ ÎêòÏñ¥ ÎãπÌô©ÌïòÏÖ®Îçò Î∂ÑÎì§ Í≥ÑÏã†Í∞ÄÏöî? Ï†ÄÎèÑ Ï†ïÎßê Ìô©ÎãπÌñàÏñ¥Ïöî. Ï±óGPT, ÏßÄÎÇúÎã¨ Î¨¥Ïä® ÏùºÏù¥ ÏûàÏóàÎÇò? 

ÏßÄÎÇú 2025ÎÖÑ 6Ïõî, Ï±óGPTÎ•º Ìè¨Ìï®Ìïú Ïò§ÌîàAI ÏÑúÎπÑÏä§Îì§Ïù¥ Îëê Ï∞®Î°ÄÏóê Í±∏Ï≥ê ÌÅ¨Í≥† ÏûëÏùÄ Ïû•Ïï†Î•º Í≤™ÏóàÏñ¥Ïöî. A: Ïò§ÌîàAIÎäî Ïã§ÏãúÍ∞Ñ Î™®ÎãàÌÑ∞ÎßÅ ÏãúÏä§ÌÖú Í≥†ÎèÑÌôî, ÏûêÎèô Î≥µÍµ¨ ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ ÎßàÎ†®, ÏãúÏä§ÌÖú Ïù¥Ï§ëÌôî Î∞è Î∂ÑÏÇ∞Ìôî, Ï£ºÍ∏∞Ï†ÅÏù∏ Ï†êÍ≤Ä Î∞è Î™®ÏùòÌõàÎ†® Îì±ÏùÑ ÌÜµÌï¥ ÏÑúÎπÑÏä§ ÏïàÏ†ïÏÑ±ÏùÑ Í∞ïÌôîÌï† ÏòàÏ†ïÏûÖÎãàÎã§.
AI Í∏∞Ïà†Ïù¥ Ïö∞Î¶¨ ÏÇ∂Ïùò ÍπäÏàôÏù¥ Îì§Ïñ¥Ïò® ÎßåÌÅº, ÏÑúÎπÑÏä§Ïùò ÏïàÏ†ïÏÑ±Í≥º Ïã†Î¢∞ÏÑ±ÏùÄ Í∑∏ Î¨¥ÏóáÎ≥¥Îã§ Ï§ëÏöîÌïú Í∞ÄÏπòÍ∞Ä ÎêòÍ≥† ÏûàÏñ¥Ïöî. Ïù¥Î≤à Ï±óGPT Ïû•Ïï† Î≥¥ÏÉÅÏ≤òÎüº ÏÇ¨ÌõÑ ÎåÄÏùëÎèÑ Î¨ºÎ°† Ï§ëÏöîÌïòÏßÄÎßå, ÏïûÏúºÎ°úÎäî Îçî ÌäºÌäºÌïú ÏãúÏä§ÌÖúÏúºÎ°ú Ïö∞Î¶¨Î•º Î∂àÌé∏ÌïòÍ≤å ÌïòÎäî ÏùºÏù¥ ÏóÜÏóàÏúºÎ©¥ Ï¢ãÍ≤†ÏäµÎãàÎã§.

posts.title: SQL Î†àÎ≤® Î≥Ñ(Lv 1~5) ÌïµÏã¨ Î¨∏Î≤ï
posts.content:
• SQL Ïó≠ÎüâÏùÑ Î†àÎ≤®Î°ú Ï†ïÏùòÌï¥Î¥§ÏäµÎãàÎã§. ÏóÖÎ¨¥Î•º ÌïòÍ≥†, ÌïôÏÉùÎì§ÏùÑ Í∞ÄÎ•¥ÏπòÎ©¥ÏÑú ÎäêÎÇÄ Î†àÎ≤®ÏùÑ Ï†ïÎ¶¨ÌñàÏñ¥Ïöî
    • Ï£ºÍ¥ÄÏ†ÅÏúºÎ°ú Ï†ïÏùòÌñàÏúºÎ©∞, DBÎäî BigQuery Í∏∞Ï§ÄÏúºÎ°ú ÏûëÏÑ±ÌñàÏäµÎãàÎã§.
    • ÏöîÏ¶ò Îç∞Ïù¥ÌÑ∞ Ïõ®Ïñ¥ÌïòÏö∞Ïä§Ï™ΩÏùÄ Î¨∏Î≤ïÏù¥ Ïú†ÏÇ¨Ìï¥ÏÑú ÌÇ§ÏõåÎìúÎßå Í∞ÄÏßÄÍ≥† Í∞ÄÏÖîÎèÑ Ï¢ãÏùÑ Í≤É Í∞ôÏäµÎãàÎã§
  • ÌÇ§ÏõåÎìú : SQL ÌïÑÏàò Î¨∏Î≤ï, BigQuery Î¨∏Î≤ï, SQL Î†àÎ≤® Î≥Ñ ÌïµÏã¨ Î¨∏Î≤ï



SQL Î¨∏Î≤ï Î†àÎ≤®Î≥Ñ ÌïµÏã¨ Ï≤¥ÌÅ¨Î¶¨Ïä§Ìä∏


SQL Í∏∞Î≥∏ ÌòïÌÉú

  • SQLÏùò Í∏∞Î≥∏ ÌòïÌÉúÎäî Îã§ÏùåÍ≥º Í∞ôÏùå(ÌïòÎÇòÏùò ÌÖåÏù¥Î∏îÏùÑ ÏÇ¨Ïö©Ìï† Í≤ΩÏö∞)
SELECT

SQL Î¨∏Î≤ï(Lv 1)

  • Ï†úÏùº Í∏∞Î≥∏Ï†ÅÏù∏ Í∞úÎÖê

SELECT : Ïª¨Îüº ÏÑ†ÌÉù, FROM : ÌÖåÏù¥Î∏î ÏßÄÏ†ï

  • ÌäπÏ†ï ÌÖåÏù¥Î∏îÏóê ÏûàÎäî Ïª¨ÎüºÏùÑ ÌôïÏù∏
  • ASÎ•º ÏÇ¨Ïö©Ìï¥ÏÑú Alias(Î≥ÑÏπ≠)ÏùÑ Ï†ïÏùòÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÏùå
SELECT
  col, 
  col2 AS new_col
FROM Table


WHERE : ÌÖåÏù¥Î∏îÏùò Ïª¨ÎüºÏóê Ï°∞Í±¥ ÏÑ§Ï†ï

  • ÌÖåÏù¥Î∏îÏóê Ï°¥Ïû¨ÌïòÎäî Ïª¨ÎüºÏóê Ï°∞Í±¥ÏùÑ ÏÑ§Ï†ïÌïòÍ≥† Ïã∂ÏùÄ Í≤ΩÏö∞ ÏÇ¨Ïö©
    • Îç∞Ïù¥ÌÑ∞ÏóêÏÑú ÌäπÏ†ï Ï°∞Í±¥ÏùÑ Ï∂©Ï°±ÌïòÎäî RowÎ•º Í∞ÄÏßÄÍ≥† Ïò§Í≥† Ïã∂ÏùÄ Í≤ΩÏö∞ ÏÇ¨Ïö©
SELECT
  col,
  col2 AS new_col
FROM Table
WHERE
  col2 = 3


GROUP BY : ÏßëÍ≥ÑÌï† Í∏∞Ï§Ä Î™ÖÏãú

  • Îç∞Ïù¥ÌÑ∞Î•º ÌäπÏ†ï Í∑∏Î£πÏúºÎ°ú Î¨∂Ïñ¥ÏÑú(ÏßëÍ≥Ñ) Ïì∞Í≥† Ïã∂ÏùÑ Îïå ÏÇ¨Ïö©
    • GROUP BYÏóê Í∑∏Î£πÌôîÌï† Ïª¨ÎüºÏùÑ Î™ÖÏãúÌïòÍ≥†, SELECTÏóêÎèÑ Î™ÖÏãúÎ•º Ìï¥Ï§òÏïº Ìï®
SELECT
  type1,
  type2,
  COUNT(*) AS cnt
FROM Table
GROUP BY 
  type1, 
  type2
  • BigQueryÏóêÏÑúÎäî GROUP BY ALLÏùÑ ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÌïòÎ©¥ ÏïåÏïÑÏÑú ÏßëÍ≥ÑÌï† Ïª¨ÎüºÏùÑ Ï∂îÎ°†Ìï¥ÏÑú Ïã§ÌñâÌï®


COUNT(col) : col Í∞úÏàò ÏÑ∏Í∏∞, DISTINCT : Í≥†Ïú†Í∞í Ï∂îÏ∂ú(Ï§ëÎ≥µ Ï†úÍ±∞)

  • COUNT(*) : Ïª¨ÎüºÏùò Row ÏàòÎ•º ÏÑºÎã§. RowÎäî Í∞íÏù¥ NULLÏù¥Ïó¨ÎèÑ ÏÑºÎã§
  • COUNT(Ïª¨Îüº) : Ïª¨ÎüºÏùò Í∞íÏùò ÏàòÎ•º ÏÑºÎã§. Í∞íÏù¥ NULLÏù¥Î©¥ ÏÑ∏ÏßÄ ÏïäÎäîÎã§
  • COUNT(DISTINCT Ïª¨Îüº) : Ïª¨ÎüºÏùò Í∞íÏùò Í≥†Ïú†Í∞í(Ï§ëÎ≥µ Ï†úÏô∏Ìïú Í∞í)ÏùÑ ÏÑºÎã§
SELECT
  type1,
  type2,
  COUNT(*) AS cnt1,
  COUNT(id) AS cnt2,
  COUNT(DISTINCT id) AS cnt3
FROM Table
GROUP BY 
  type1, 
  type2

AVG, MAX, MIN

  • ÌèâÍ∑†, ÏµúÎåÄÍ∞í, ÏµúÏÜåÍ∞í


HAVING : ÏßëÍ≥Ñ ÌõÑ Ïª¨ÎüºÏóê Ï°∞Í±¥ ÏÑ§Ï†ï

  • GROUP BYÏôÄ Í∞ôÏù¥ ÏÇ¨Ïö©Îê®
  • GROUP BY ÌõÑÏóê Ï°∞Í±¥ÏùÑ ÏÑ§Ï†ïÌïòÍ≥† Ïã∂ÏùÄ Í≤ΩÏö∞ ÏÇ¨Ïö©
    • (ÎπÑÍµê) WHERE : ÌÖåÏù¥Î∏îÏùò Ïª¨ÎüºÏóê Ï°∞Í±¥ ÏÑ§Ï†ï, HAVINGÏùÄ GROUP BY ÌõÑÏóê Ï°∞Í±¥ ÏÑ§Ï†ï
SELECT
  type1,
  type2,
  COUNT(*) AS cnt
FROM Table
GROUP BY 
  type1, 
  type2
HAVING cnt >=3


ORDER BY: Ï†ïÎ†¨

  • Îç∞Ïù¥ÌÑ∞Î•º Ï†ïÎ†¨ÌïòÍ≥† Ïã∂ÏùÄ Í≤ΩÏö∞ ÏÇ¨Ïö©
    • ÏøºÎ¶¨Ïùò Ï§ëÍ∞ÑÏóê ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÍ≥† ÏøºÎ¶¨ Ï†úÏùº Î∞îÍπ•(ÎßàÏßÄÎßâ) ÏøºÎ¶¨Ïóê Ïã§ÌñâÌïòÎäî Í≤ÉÏù¥ Ï¢ãÏùå
    • ORDER BYÎäî Î™®Îì† Îç∞Ïù¥ÌÑ∞Î•º Îã§ ÌôïÏù∏Ìï¥ÏÑú Ï†ïÎ†¨ÏùÑ ÌïòÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïóê ÏãúÍ∞ÑÏù¥ ÏÜåÏöîÎê®
  • ASC(Ïò§Î¶ÑÏ∞®Ïàú), DESC(ÎÇ¥Î¶ºÏ∞®Ïàú)
SELECT
  type1,
  type2,
  COUNT(*) AS cnt
FROM Table
GROUP BY 
  type1, 
  type2
HAVING cnt >=3
ORDER BY cnt DESC


LIMIT : Ï∂úÎ†•Ìï† Í∞úÏàò Ï†úÌïú

  • Ï∂úÎ†•Ìï† Í∞úÏàò Ï†úÌïúÌïòÍ≥† Ïã∂ÏùÑ Îïå ÏÇ¨Ïö©
SELECT
  type1,
  type2,
  COUNT(*) AS cnt
FROM Table
GROUP BY 
  type1, 
  type2
HAVING cnt >=3
ORDER BY cnt DESC
LIMIT 3



SQL Î¨∏Î≤ï(Lv 2)

Ï°∞Í±¥Î¨∏(CASE WHEN, IF)

  • Ï°∞Í±¥ÏùÑ ÏÑ§Ï†ïÌïòÍ≥† Ïã∂ÏùÄ Í≤ΩÏö∞
  • Îã§Ï§ë Ï°∞Í±¥ÏùÄ CASE WHEN Ï∂îÏ≤ú
SELECT
  CASE 
    WHEN Ï°∞Í±¥1 THEN Í≤∞Í≥º1
    WHEN Ï°∞Í±¥2 THEN Í≤∞Í≥º2
    ELSE Î™®ÎëêÏïÑÎãêÎïå
  END AS case_result
FROM Table

SELECT
  IF(Ï°∞Í±¥, Ï°∞Í±¥Ïù¥ Ï∞∏Ïùº Îïå Í∞í, Ï°∞Í±¥Ïù¥ Í±∞ÏßìÏùº Îïå Í∞í) AS if_result
FROM Table


ÏãúÍ∞Ñ Îç∞Ïù¥ÌÑ∞ Îã§Î£®Í∏∞

  • ÏãúÍ∞Ñ, Ïõî Ï∂îÏ∂ú
  • ÌäπÏ†ï ÏùºÏûê Í∏∞Ï§ÄÏúºÎ°ú Î≤ÑÎ¶¨Í∏∞
  • TIMESTAMP, DATETIME Í∞úÎÖê
  • UTC Í∞úÎÖêÎèÑ ÏïåÎ©¥ Ï¢ãÏùå
  • BigQuery Í∏∞Ï§ÄÏúºÎ°ú ÏÑ§Î™Ö
SELECT
  EXTRACT(HOUR FROM datetime_col) AS hour
FROM Table


JOIN : Ïó¨Îü¨ ÌÖåÏù¥Î∏îÏùÑ Ïó∞Í≤∞Ìï† Îïå ÏÇ¨Ïö©

  • INNER, LEFT, RIGHT, CROSS JOIN
  • ON ÏÇ¨Ïö©Ìï¥ÏÑú Í≥µÌÜµ Key Ïó∞Í≤∞
SELECT
  lt.id,
  lt.col1,
  rt.col4
FROM left_table AS lt
LEFT JOIN right_table AS rt
ON lt.id = rt.id



SQL Î¨∏Î≤ï(Lv 3)

ÏúàÎèÑÏö∞ Ìï®Ïàò

  • ÏΩîÎî© ÌÖåÏä§Ìä∏ÏóêÏÑú ÏûêÏ£º Ï∂úÏ†úÎêòÎäî Ïú†Ìòï
  • Ïù¥Ï†Ñ/Ïù¥ÌõÑ : LAG/LEAD
  • Ï≤òÏùå, ÎßàÏßÄÎßâ Í∞í : FIRST_VALUE, LAST_VALUE
  • ÏàúÏÑú ÌôïÏù∏ : ROW_NUMBER, RANK, DENSE_RANK
  • ÏúàÎèÑÏö∞ Ìï®Ïàò Î¨∏Î≤ï
    • Ìï®Ïàò(Ïª¨Îüº) OVER(PARTITION BY ÌååÌã∞ÏÖòÏª¨Îüº ORDER BY Ï†ïÎ†¨Ïª¨Îüº)
SELECT
  LAG(event_time) OVER (PARTITION BY user_id ORDER BY event_time) AS prev_event_time,
  FIRST_VALUE(event_time) OVER (PARTITION BY user_id ORDER BY event_time) AS first_event_time
FROM Table

SELECT
  DENSE_RANK() OVER (PARTITION BY team ORDER BY cnt) AS rank
FROM Table


WITHÎ¨∏(CTE)

  • ÏøºÎ¶¨Î•º Ïûò Ï†ïÎ¶¨ÌïòÍ≥† Ïã∂ÏùÑ Îïå ÏÇ¨Ïö©
  • ÏÑúÎ∏åÏøºÎ¶¨Î•º ÏûëÏÑ±ÌïòÍ≥† Ï†ïÎ¶¨Ìï† Îïå ÏûêÏ£º ÏÇ¨Ïö©Ìï®

  SELECT
    col2, col3
  FROM Table
)

SELECT 
  * 
FROM cte



SQL Î¨∏Î≤ï(Lv 4)

ÏúàÎèÑÏö∞ Ìï®Ïàò(Frame Ï°∞Ï†à)

  • AVG, SUM Ìï®ÏàòÏôÄ Ìï®Íªò Frame Ï°∞Ï†à
  • Ïù¥Îèô ÌèâÍ∑† Íµ¨Ìï† Îïå ÌôúÏö©
  • Ìï®Ïàò(Ïª¨Îüº) OVER(PARTITION BY ÌååÌã∞ÏÖòÏª¨Îüº ORDER BY Ï†ïÎ†¨Ïª¨Îüº ROWS BETWEEN UNBOUNDED PRECEDING AND UNBOUNDED FOLLOWING)
  • CURRENT ROW : ÌòÑÏû¨ ROW
  • UNBOUNDED : ÎÅùÍπåÏßÄ
  • PRECEDING : Ïù¥Ï†Ñ
  • FOLLOWING Ïù¥ÌõÑ
  • ÏúàÎèÑÏö∞ Ìï®ÏàòÏùò ORDER BY Îí§Ïóê Ïì∞Î©¥ Îê®
SELECT
  SUM(value) OVER (PARTITION BY user_id ORDER BY order_date) AS cumulative_sum
FROM table


ARRAY, STRUCT

  • Î∞∞Ïó¥, Íµ¨Ï°∞Ï≤¥ Îç∞Ïù¥ÌÑ∞Î•º Îã§Î£∞ Îïå ÏÇ¨Ïö©
  • GA4, Firebase Îç∞Ïù¥ÌÑ∞ Îã§Î£∞ Îïå ÌïÑÏàò
  • PostgreSQL, BigQuery, Apache Spark Îì±Ïóê Ï°¥Ïû¨ÌïòÎ©∞ Î¨∏Î≤ïÏù¥ Îã§ÏñëÌï®


GROUP BY GROUPING SETS/ROLLUP/CUBE

  • GROUP BYÏùò ÌôïÏû•Ìåê
  • ÏßëÍ≥ÑÎ•º Îçî Ìé∏ÌïòÍ≤å Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÏùå
    • ÏïÑÎûò ÏøºÎ¶¨Îäî category, region Î≥Ñ ÏßëÍ≥Ñ + region Î≥Ñ ÏßëÍ≥Ñ + Ï†ÑÏ≤¥ ÏßëÍ≥Ñ
SELECT 
  category,
  region,
  SUM(sales_amount) AS total_sales,
  COUNT(*) AS transaction_count
FROM sales
GROUP BY GROUPING SETS (
  (category, region),
  (region),
  ()
)



SQL Î¨∏Î≤ï(Lv 5)

JSON

  • JSON ÌòïÌÉúÏóêÏÑú Îç∞Ïù¥ÌÑ∞ Ï∂îÏ∂ú

  • DBÎßàÎã§ Î¨∏Î≤ï Îã§ÏñëÌï®


Ï†ïÍ∑úÌëúÌòÑÏãù

  • ÌÖçÏä§Ìä∏ Îç∞Ïù¥ÌÑ∞ÏóêÏÑú Îç∞Ïù¥ÌÑ∞ Ï∂îÏ∂ú

  • ÌååÏù¥Ïç¨ÏóêÏÑú Ìï®Ïàò Ïì∞Îäî Í≤ÉÏ≤òÎüº Ï†ïÏùòÌï¥ÏÑú Ïì∏ Ïàò ÏûàÏùå

ÏÜåÎìùÏàòÏ§ÄÏù¥ Ïò¨ÎùºÍ∞êÏóê Îî∞Îùº

ÌïòÏßÄÎßå Ï§ëÍµ≠ÏùÄ Íµ≠ÎØºÏùÑ Ï†úÏñ¥Ìï¥ÏïºÌïòÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïóê ÎÜÄÎ¶¨Î©¥ Î¨∏Ï†úÍ∞Ä ÏÉùÍ∏∏ Ïó¨ÏßÄÍ∞Ä Ïª§ÏßÄÍ≤å Îê©ÎãàÎã§.

Î∞±ÏóîÎìú Í∞úÎ∞úÏûêÎ°ú Ï†ïÏÇ∞ ÏãúÏä§ÌÖúÏùÑ Îß°Îã§ Î≥¥Î©¥ ÌöåÏÇ¨ ÏïàÏóêÏÑú Î≤åÏñ¥ÏßÄÎäî Í±∞Ïùò Î™®Îì† ÏÇ¨ÏóÖ Î™®Îç∏ÏùÑ Ìïú Î≤àÏî©ÏùÄ Îì§Ïó¨Îã§Î≥¥Í≤å ÎêúÎã§.
ÏßÅÏ†ë Îß§Ï∂úÏùÑ ÎßåÎì§ÏßÑ ÏïäÏßÄÎßå, Î™®Îì† ÏÑúÎπÑÏä§Í∞Ä Ïñ¥ÎñªÍ≤å ÎèàÏùÑ Î≤åÍ≥†, ÎàÑÍµ∞Í∞ÄÏóêÍ≤å ÏñºÎßàÎ•º Ï§òÏïº ÌïòÎäîÏßÄÎ•º Í∞ÄÏû• Í∞ÄÍπåÏù¥ÏÑú Î≥¥Í≤å ÎêòÎäî ÏúÑÏπòÏóê ÏûàÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïù¥Îã§.

Ï†Ñ ÌöåÏÇ¨ÏóêÏÑú ÏùºÌï† ÎãπÏãú, 5.8%Ïùò Ï£ºÎ¨∏ ÏàòÏàòÎ£å Î™®Îç∏ÏùÑ Îü∞Ïπ≠ÌñàÎã§.
Í∏∞Ï°¥Ïóî Ïõî 8Îßå ÏõêÏî© Í≥†Ï†ï Í¥ëÍ≥†ÎπÑ(ÏùºÎ™Ö ‘ÍπÉÎ∞úÍΩÇÍ∏∞’)Î•º ÎÇ¥Îäî Íµ¨Ï°∞ÏóêÏÑú Ï£ºÎ¨∏ Í±¥Îãπ ÏàòÏàòÎ£å Î™®Îç∏Î°úÏùò Ï†ÑÌôòÏù¥ÏòÄÎã§.

Ï≤òÏùå ÏÑ§Î™ÖÏùÑ Îì§ÏùÑÎïåÎäî "Ïù¥Î†áÍ≤å ÎêòÎ©¥ ÎèàÏùÑ Î≤åÏàòÎ°ù ÎÇ¥Îäî ÎπÑÏö©Ïù¥ Ïª§ÏßÄÎäîÎç∞ Ïù¥Í±∏ ÎàÑÍ∞ÄÌï¥??" ÎùºÎäî ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÏù¥ÏòÄÎã§.
Í∑∏Îü¨Îã§Í∞Ä ÌîÑÎ°úÏ†ùÌä∏ ÏÑ§Î™ÖÏùÑ Îì§ÏúºÎ©¥ÏÑú ÌòÑÏû¨ Î™®Îç∏Ïù¥ Í∞ñÍ≥† ÏûàÎäî ÌïúÍ≥ÑÎ•º Ïù¥Ìï¥ÌïòÎ©¥ÏÑú ÎÇ©ÎìùÏù¥ ÎêòÏóàÎã§.

ÎãπÏãúÏóêÎäî Ïõî 8ÎßåÏõêÏùò Í¥ëÍ≥† Î™®Îç∏ (a.k.a ÍπÉÎ∞úÍΩÇÍ∏∞) ÏùÑ ÏàòÏã≠Í∞úÏî© ÌôúÏö©ÌïòÏãúÎäî Î∂ÑÎì§Ïù¥ Í≥ÑÏÖîÏÑú Í¥ëÍ≥†ÎπÑÏóê ÎßéÏùÄ ÎπÑÏö©ÏùÑ Ìà¨ÏûêÌïòÍ∏∞ ÌûòÎì† ÏòÅÏÑ∏Ìïú ÏûêÏòÅÏóÖÏûêÎ∂ÑÎì§ÏùÄ Í∞ÄÍ≤å ÎÖ∏Ï∂ú ÌïòÍ∏∞Í∞Ä ÏâΩÏßÄ ÏïäÏïòÎã§.

Í¥ëÍ≥† Î™®Îç∏Ïùò Ïû•Ï†êÏùÄ ÏïÑÎ¨¥Î¶¨ Îß§Ï∂úÏù¥ ÎßéÏù¥ ÎÇòÎèÑ ÎÇòÍ∞ÄÎäî ÎπÑÏö©Ïù¥ Í≥†Ï†ïÎêòÏñ¥ÏûàÎã§Îäî Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§.
Î∞òÎ©¥, ÎÖ∏Ï∂úÏùÄ Í¥ëÍ≥†ÎπÑ ÏòÅÌñ•ÏùÑ Î∞õÎã§Î≥¥Îãà ÎßõÏûàÎäî ÏùåÏãùÏùÑ ÎßåÎì§Ïñ¥ÎèÑ Ï¥àÍ∏∞Ïóê ÏûêÍ∏àÏù¥ ÏóÜÏúºÎ©¥ ÏÜåÎπÑÏûêÏùò ÏÑ†ÌÉùÏùÑ Î∞õÍ∏∞Í∞Ä ÏâΩÏßÄ ÏïäÏïòÎã§.

ÏùåÏãùÏùÑ Ï£ºÎ¨∏ÌïòÎäî ÏÜåÎπÑÏûêÎ∂ÑÎì§Ïù¥ ÎßéÏù¥ ÏÑ†ÌÉùÌïòÍ≥† ÎÜíÏùÄ ÎßåÏ°±ÎèÑÎ•º ÎÇ∏Í≤ÉÏóê Îî∞ÎùºÎßå ÎÖ∏Ï∂ú Ï†ïÏ±ÖÏù¥ Í≤∞Ï†ïÎêòÏïºÌïòÎäîÎç∞, Í¥ëÍ≥† Î™®Îç∏ÏùÄ Í∑∏ ÎÖ∏Ï∂ú Ï†ïÏ±ÖÏóê Îßõ, ÌèâÍ∞Ä Ïô∏ Îã§Î•∏ ÏöîÏÜåÍ∞Ä Í∞ïÎ†•ÌïòÍ≤å Îì§Ïñ¥Í∞ÄÎäî Í≤ÉÏù¥ÏòÄÎã§.

Í∑∏ÎûòÏÑú (Ï†ÄÎ†¥Ìïú) ÏàòÏàòÎ£å Í∏∞Î∞ò Î™®Îç∏Î°ú Ï†ÑÌôòÌïòÎ©¥ Îçî ÎßéÏùÄ Í∞ÄÍ≤åÎì§Ïù¥ Í≥µÏ†ïÌïú Í∏∞ÌöåÎ•º Í∞ÄÏßà Ïàò ÏûàÍ≤†Îã§Í≥† ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïòÎãà Ïù¥ ÌîÑÎ°úÏ†ùÌä∏Î•º ÎÇ©ÎìùÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÏóàÎã§.

Ìï¥Îãπ Î™®Îç∏Î°ú Î≥ÄÌôòÌï¥ÏÑú Í≥ÑÏÇ∞Ìï¥Î≥¥Îãà Ïó∞ Îß§Ï∂ú 3ÏñµÏù¥Ìïò Îß§Ïû•ÍπåÏßÄÍ∞Ä Îçî Ï†ÄÎ†¥ÌïòÍ≤å ÏàòÏàòÎ£åÎ•º ÎÇ¥Í≥†, 58% ÏûêÏòÅÏóÖÏûêÎ∂ÑÎì§Ïù¥ ÎåÄÏÉÅÏù¥ ÎêòÎãà Í∑∏Í≤ÉÎèÑ Ï¢ãÏïòÎã§.

ÎπÑÏ¶àÎãàÏä§ Î™®Îç∏Ïù¥ Ïû•Í∏∞Ï†ÅÏúºÎ°ú ‘Í±¥Í∞ïÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÎäêÎÉê’Ïóê ÎåÄÌïú ÎÇ¥ Ï≤´ Í≥†ÎØºÏù¥Í∏∞ÎèÑ ÌñàÎã§.
(Î¨ºÎ°† Ïù¥ ÌîÑÎ°úÏ†ùÌä∏Îäî Í≤∞Íµ≠ Î°§Î∞±ÎêêÏßÄÎßå, Ïù¥ Í≤ΩÌóòÏù¥ ÎÇ¥ ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÏùÑ ÎßéÏù¥ Î∞îÍøîÎÜ®Îã§.)

Ïù∏ÌîÑÎü∞ Ìï©Î•ò ÌõÑ ÎßéÏùÄ Î∂ÑÎì§Ïù¥ Ïù∏ÌîÑÎü∞ÏùÄ Íµ¨ÎèÖÏ†ú ÏïàÌïòÎÉêÎäî Î¨∏ÏùòÎ•º ÎßéÏù¥ Ï£ºÏÖ®Îã§.
Îã§Î•∏ ÍµêÏú° ÌîåÎû´ÌèºÎì§Ïù¥ Í∏∞ÏóÖ Íµ¨ÎèÖ ÏÑúÎπÑÏä§Î•º ÌÜµÌï¥ Îß§Ï∂úÏùÑ ÎäòÎ¶¨Îäî ÎèôÏïàÏóêÎèÑ Ïö∞Î¶¨Îäî Îã®Í±¥ Í≤∞Ï†ú Ï§ëÏã¨Ïùò Íµ¨Ï°∞Î•º Í≥†ÏàòÌñàÎã§.

Í∑∏ Ïù¥Ïú†Îäî Îã®ÏàúÌñàÎã§.

Íµ¨ÎèÖ Î™®Îç∏Ïù¥ Ïª§ÏßàÏàòÎ°ù,
Í∞ïÏùòÏùò ‘ÌíàÏßà’Î≥¥Îã§Îäî ‘Í∏∏Ïù¥’Í∞Ä Ï§ëÏöîÌï¥ÏßàÍπå Í±±Ï†ïÎêêÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïù¥Îã§.

Ï†ïÌï¥ÏßÑ Ï†ïÏÇ∞ Í∏àÏï° ÏïàÏóêÏÑú ÏòÅÏÉÅ Ïû¨ÏÉù ÏãúÍ∞ÑÏù¥ Í∏∏ÏàòÎ°ù Îçî ÎßéÏùÄ ÏàòÏùµÏù¥ ÎèåÏïÑÍ∞ÄÎäî Íµ¨Ï°∞Îäî Í≤∞Íµ≠ ÏΩòÌÖêÏ∏†Ïùò ÌÄÑÎ¶¨Ìã∞Î≥¥Îã§ ÌîåÎ†àÏù¥ÌÉÄÏûÑ ÏµúÏ†ÅÌôîÏóê ÏßëÏ§ëÌïòÍ≤å ÎßåÎì†Îã§.

Ïö∞Î¶¨Îäî Í∑∏ Í∏∏ÏùÑ Í∞ÄÍ≥† Ïã∂ÏßÄ ÏïäÏïòÎã§.
ÏàòÏ≤ú Î™ÖÏùò ÏßÄÏãùÍ≥µÏú†ÏûêÎì§Ïù¥ ‘ÏßÑÏßú ÎèÑÏõÄÏù¥ ÎêòÎäî ÏßÄÏãù’ÏùÑ ÎßåÎì§Í≥† ÏûàÎã§Îäî Í±∏ ÏïåÍ≥† ÏûàÏóàÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïù¥Îã§.
Í∑∏ÎûòÏÑú Í∑∏ Í∞ÄÏπòÎ•º Ï†úÎåÄÎ°ú Î≥¥ÏÉÅÎ∞õÎäî Íµ¨Ï°∞Î•º ÏßÄÌÇ§Í≥† Ïã∂ÏóàÎã§.

Í∑∏Îü¨Îã§ Ïñ¥Îäê ÎÇ†, ÎÇ¥Î∂Ä Îç∞Ïù¥ÌÑ∞Î•º Îì§Ïó¨Îã§Î≥¥Îã§ ÎÜÄÎùºÏö¥ Í±∏ Î∞úÍ≤¨ÌñàÎã§.
Ï¢ãÏùÄ ÏΩòÌÖêÏ∏†Îäî Î∞òÎ≥µÌï¥ÏÑú Î≥µÏäµÎêúÎã§Îäî Í≤É.

Ìïú Î≤à Î≥¥Í≥† ÎÅùÎÇòÎäî ÏΩòÌÖêÏ∏†Í∞Ä ÏïÑÎãàÎùº, ÏßÑÏßúÎ°ú ÌïÑÏöîÌïú ÏÇ¨ÎûåÎì§ÏùÄ Í∞ôÏùÄ Í∞ïÏùòÎ•º 2Î≤à, 3Î≤à Îã§Ïãú Îì£Í≥† Ï¶êÍ≤®Ï∞æÍ∏∞Î•º Ìï¥ÎëêÍ≥† Ïä¨ÎûôÏù¥ÎÇò ÏÇ¨ÎÇ¥ ÏúÑÌÇ§Ïóê Í≥µÏú†ÌïòÍ≥† ÏûàÏóàÎã§.

Í≤∞Íµ≠ Ï§ëÏöîÌïú Í±¥ Í∏∏Ïù¥Í∞Ä ÏïÑÎãàÎùº,

“ÏñºÎßàÎÇò Îã§Ïãú Îì£Í≥† Ïã∂Í≤å ÎßåÎìúÎäîÍ∞Ä”
“ÏñºÎßàÎÇò Ïã§Î¨¥Ïóê ÎèÑÏõÄÏù¥ ÎêòÎäîÍ∞Ä”
ÏòÄÎã§.
